{"uri": "2024-04-333222394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "00:55:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T00:55:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T00:53:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/sports/article287958155.html", "title": "Taxpayers would pick up half the tab for Bears' lakefront stadium, sources say", "body": "By Robert McCoppin, Jeremy Gorner, Dan Petrella and Brian J. Rogal, Chicago Tribune The Tribune Content Agency\n\nCHICAGO - The Chicago Bears are set to announce a $4.6 billion plan for a new enclosed stadium and lakefront area, half of which would come from taxpayers, sources said, but the team will have to overcome serious skepticism from several directions.\n\nThe stadium itself would cost $3.2 billion to build, with another $1.4 billion in proposed infrastructure improvements, according to sources familiar with the plan who spoke to the Chicago Tribune on the condition of anonymity.\n\nThe sources said the Bears plan to pledge $2.3 billion, which include some financing through the NFL. But the Bears' plan includes an additional $2.3 billion in public financing, along with refinancing outstanding debt for prior publicly financed stadium projects for the Bears and White Sox, according to the sources.\n\nTaxpayers would be on the hook for the proposed infrastructure improvements along with about $1 billion in new borrowing to finance the new stadium south of Soldier Field, the sources said.\n\nTo make the plan a reality, the Bears want the Illinois General Assembly to approve $1.5 billion in new bonding for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which carries the debt for prior projects at Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, sources said.\n\nAbout one-third of the new borrowing would be used to roll over existing stadium debt, and the plan calls for the new borrowing to be paid off over 40 years, which also would require legislative approval.\n\nSources said the Bears' plan calls for the debt to be repaid without raising the 2% hotel tax that currently goes to ISFA.\n\nThe details are expected to be revealed at a much-anticipated news conference at noon Wednesday where officials will lay out plans for the domed stadium with increased open space.\n\nThe 2% hotel tax has fallen far short of paying off the existing debt. As a result, taxpayers still owe $629 million for past renovations of Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, whose occupants, the White Sox, also are seeking a new stadium in the South Loop. To finance a new Bears stadium using the hotel tax, the state would have to increase the borrowing limit for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nThat could prove to be a tough sell in Springfield, however, where legislative leaders so far have given the Bears, and the Sox, a cool reception.\n\nThen there is the question of whether the Bears can legally build on the site. The city's lakefront protection ordinance calls for public use of the lakefront, and the team has called for public ownership of the stadium.\n\nThe nonprofit Friends of the Parks opposes building a stadium for a privately owned team on the lakefront. The group successfully drove \"Star Wars\" creator George Lucas away from plans to build a movie art museum on the same site, now used for parking lots.\n\nWhatever the Bears propose, they will have to win over skeptics, including Gov. J.B. Pritzker, who a spokesperson said Tuesday had not been briefed by the team about the stadium plans. The governor had previously called the Bears' proposed investment \"a good first step,\" and said he's willing to listen to their proposal, but said it shouldn't be a priority for the state.\n\nJoe Ferguson, president of the Civic Federation, a fiscal watchdog group, told the Tribune in a recent interview that the Bears and Sox need to show vetted cost and revenue projections.\n\n\"Everybody wants to keep the teams (in the city) - the question is, on what terms?\" he said. \"There's not a lot of information necessary to say one of these (plans) actually is viable, or whether it's a way to take us to the cleaners when we're already carrying hundreds of millions of dollars of debt for the last time we did something like this.\"\n\nThe city recently went through a similar scenario, he said, when it chose the Bally's casino for development, only to find the project is already being scaled back and has funding issues.\n\n\"I think Gov. Pritzker has spoken to this exactly right, with a real wariness about public funding of sports stadiums,\" Ferguson said. \"We need to see reliable, thorough revenue projections for this before we can even open the conversation.\"\n\nMaking the situation more precarious, Ferguson said, is that all levels of government are facing financial cliffs in multiple areas - pensions, transit and Chicago Public Schools -with the end of billions of dollars in federal COVID-19 pandemic money.\n\nSports economist J.C. Bradbury, voicing a common concern among economists, said whatever public money is earmarked for the stadium would be better spent on other public projects, or returned to taxpayers.\n\n\"Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me,\" Bradbury said. \"The Bears aren't going to leave one of the most iconic football markets in the country. Tell the Bears to pay for their own damn stadium, and if they don't like it, to go jump in Lake Michigan.\"\n\nThe team has taken a long, strange trip to get to this point. In 2022, officials agreed to buy the former Arlington International Racecourse for $197 million, closing on the deal last year. Under prior President and CEO Ted Phillips, the team made an elaborate presentation of its plans for a $5 billion mixed-used development on the 326-acre site, with an enclosed stadium, housing and entertainment.\n\nBut since Kevin Warren became team president and CEO last year, the team has been unable to reach agreement over property taxes with local schools in the Arlington Heights area.\n\nAs the Minnesota Vikings did when Warren was an executive there, the Bears reversed course from a suburban stadium site to downtown. Warren has extolled the beauty and energy of the city, talked of his rapport with Mayor Brandon Johnson, and has said the lakefront is the \"ideal location.\"\n\n\"Absolutely we can build something that would be magnificent downtown,\" he said.\n\nThe team wouldn't necessarily have to move right away, with a lease at Soldier Field through 2033. But Warren has talked about the importance of momentum in getting the stadium project done. State lawmakers are scheduled to meet until May 24, then have a veto session in the fall, and a brief lame-duck session in the new year.\n\nReconstructing the museum campus around a new Bears stadium could help attract new residential and retail development along the lakefront, replacing some of the tax revenue lost by the declining property values of downtown office towers, said Eric Feinberg, vice chairman and co-head of the Chicago region for Savills, a commercial real estate firm.\n\nIf the Bears' proposal improves lakefront access with better public transportation with new gathering spaces, it's possible the new stadium district will attract families year-round, not just on a handful of Sundays.\n\nFeinberg said he still doesn't understand why the Bears didn't settle disagreements with Arlington Heights' officials before buying the former Churchill Downs site.\n\n\"It seems so strange they would plop down all this money, and then say this is just not working out for us,\" he said. \"It boggles my mind.\"\n\nIf the Bears do cut a deal for a lakefront stadium, it would leave Arlington Heights with a big hole to fill, said John Melaniphy of Melaniphy & Associates, a former business and development coordinator for the village of Arlington Heights. But even without football, the former racetrack site could still attract mixed-use developments with apartments, restaurants and entertainment.", "source": {"uri": "bradenton.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8095594519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:45:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:45:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:44:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13347009/Bears-unveil-plan-lakefront-stadium-seek-public-funding-make-happen.html", "title": "Bears unveil plan for lakefront stadium and seek public funding to...", "body": "CHICAGO (AP) - The Chicago Bears unveiled a nearly $5 billion proposal Wednesday for an enclosed stadium next door to their current home at Soldier Field as part of a major project that would transform the city's lakefront, and they are asking for public funding to help make it happen.\n\nThe plan calls for $3.2 billion for the new stadium plus an additional $1.5 billion in infrastructure. The team and the city said the project would add green and open space while improving access to the city's Museum Campus and could also include a publicly owned hotel.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said.\n\nThe announcement at Soldier Field comes during a busy week for the Bears. They are expected to take 2022 Heisman Trophy winner Caleb Williams with the No. 1 pick in the draft on Thursday night and bank on the USC quarterback to solidify a position that has long been a sore spot for the founding NFL franchise.\n\nThe team said last month it was prepared to provide more than $2 billion in funding toward a publicly owned stadium in the city.\n\nThe proposal calls for $2.025 billion from the Bears, $300 million from an NFL loan and $900 million in bonds from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority. The funding from the ISFA would involve extending bonds of the existing 2% hotel tax.\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson returns to his seat after speaking at the unveiling in Chicago on April 23, 2024. The Chicago Bears unveiled a nearly $5 billion proposal Wednesday for an enclosed stadium next door to their current home at Soldier Field as part of a major project that would transform the city's lakefront, and they are asking for public funding to help make it happen. The plan calls for $3.2 billion for the new stadium plus an additional $1.5 billion in infrastructure. (AP Photo/Teresa Crawford)\n\nThe Bears said the project would generate $8 billion in economic impact for the region. It would be built in three phases and take up to five years. The new stadium would be constructed on a parking lot just south of Soldier Field, the Bears' home since 1971. The team\u00b4s lease at the 100-year-old stadium runs through 2033.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson gave a full-throated endorsement, saying the project is in line with Daniel Burnham's \"Plan of Chicago.\" He said there would be no tax hikes or new taxes for Chicago residents.\n\nRenderings show the Bears\u00b4 stadium would have a translucent roof and massive glass panels that would bring in sunlight and allow for views of Chicago\u00b4s famed skyline. The plan is to host major concerts throughout the year as well as Super Bowls, Final Fours and Big Ten championship games.\n\nThough Soldier Field\u00b4s famed colonnades would be preserved, the spaceship-like stadium that was installed in the renovation two decades ago would be torn out and replaced by playing fields as well as park space. The plan calls for a pedestrian mall, food and beverage options, a promenade and plaza.\n\n\"My administration insisted that any new project - especially one on public land - must deliver strong public benefit and public use for the City of Chicago, and I am pleased today that this plan does exactly that,\" Johnson said.\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, however, said he wasn\u00b4t on board.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal and I wonder whether it\u00b4s a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker told reporters Wednesday at an unrelated news conference. \"I\u00b4m not sure this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nIllinois\u00b4 top legislative leaders were also doubtful.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Illinois House Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch said at an unrelated news conference. \"There is no environment for something like this today.\"\n\nHowever, he added that the environment in Springfield does change.\n\nThe proposal comes as two other Chicago sports teams, including the White Sox and Red Stars, have expressed interest in public funding for new stadiums.\n\nWarren, who replaced the retired Ted Phillips a year ago, played a big role in the construction of U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis through a public-private partnership when he worked in the Minnesota Vikings\u00b4 front office from 2005 to 2019.\n\nThe Bears spent $197.2 million more than a year ago to purchase the site of the shuttered Arlington International Racecourse from Churchill Downs Inc. They envisioned building a stadium on the 326-acre tract of land some 30 miles northwest of Soldier Field, with restaurants, retail and more on the property - all for about $5 billion, with some taxpayer help.\n\nThe Bears had said they would pay for the stadium in Arlington Heights, with taxpayer dollars covering infrastructure costs such as roads and sewers. Those plans stalled, with the team citing a property assessment it said was too high.\n\nThey would remain tenants by staying in Chicago rather than owning a stadium in Arlington Heights. But Warren said he sees it as more of a partnership with the city rather than a landlord-tenant relationship.\n\n\"I believe in Mayor Johnson,\" Warren said. \"I believe in his staff, his vision, I believe in this city. I don't look at it as being a renter. I look at it as being able to develop a relationship, to be able to come together. People asked that same question in Minnesota - why would you want to be a renter?\"\n\nAssociated Press reporter Sophia Tareen in Chicago contributed to this report. ___\n\nAP NFL: {"uri": "2024-04-334399057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:52:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:52:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/bears-unveil-plan-for-lakefront-stadium-and-seek-public-funding-to-make-it-happen/article_6837fbf2-b8cd-55d3-af52-eac60c11314a.html", "title": "Bears unveil plan for lakefront stadium and seek public funding to make it happen", "body": "CHICAGO (AP) -- The Chicago Bears unveiled a nearly $5 billion proposal Wednesday for an enclosed stadium next door to their current home at Soldier Field as part of a major project that would transform the city's lakefront, and they are asking for public funding to help make it happen.\n\nThe plan calls for $3.2 billion for the new stadium plus an additional $1.5 billion in infrastructure. The team and the city said the project would add green and open space while improving access to the city's Museum Campus and could also include a publicly owned hotel.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said.\n\nThe announcement at Soldier Field comes during a busy week for the Bears. They are expected to take 2022 Heisman Trophy winner Caleb Williams with the No. 1 pick in the draft on Thursday night and bank on the USC quarterback to solidify a position that has long been a sore spot for the founding NFL franchise.\n\nThe team said last month it was prepared to provide more than $2 billion in funding toward a publicly owned stadium in the city.\n\nThe proposal calls for $2.025 billion from the Bears, $300 million from an NFL loan and $900 million in bonds from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority. The funding from the ISFA would involve extending bonds of the existing 2% hotel tax.\n\nThe Bears said the project would generate $8 billion in economic impact for the region. It would be built in three phases and take up to five years. The new stadium would be constructed on a parking lot just south of Soldier Field, the Bears' home since 1971. The team's lease at the 100-year-old stadium runs through 2033.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson gave a full-throated endorsement, saying the project is in line with Daniel Burnham's \"Plan of Chicago.\" He said there would be no tax hikes or new taxes for Chicago residents.\n\nRenderings show the Bears' stadium would have a translucent roof and massive glass panels that would bring in sunlight and allow for views of Chicago's famed skyline. The plan is to host major concerts throughout the year as well as Super Bowls, Final Fours and Big Ten championship games.\n\nThough Soldier Field's famed colonnades would be preserved, the spaceship-like stadium that was installed in the renovation two decades ago would be torn out and replaced by playing fields as well as park space. The plan calls for a pedestrian mall, food and beverage options, a promenade and plaza.\n\n\"My administration insisted that any new project -- especially one on public land -- must deliver strong public benefit and public use for the City of Chicago, and I am pleased today that this plan does exactly that,\" Johnson said.\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, however, said he wasn't on board.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal and I wonder whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker told reporters Wednesday at an unrelated news conference. \"I'm not sure this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nIllinois' top legislative leaders were also doubtful.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Illinois House Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch said at an unrelated news conference. \"There is no environment for something like this today.\"\n\nHowever, he added that the environment in Springfield does change.\n\nThe proposal comes as two other Chicago sports teams, including the White Sox and Red Stars, have expressed interest in public funding for new stadiums.\n\nWarren, who replaced the retired Ted Phillips a year ago, played a big role in the construction of U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis through a public-private partnership when he worked in the Minnesota Vikings' front office from 2005 to 2019.\n\nThe Bears spent $197.2 million more than a year ago to purchase the site of the shuttered Arlington International Racecourse from Churchill Downs Inc. They envisioned building a stadium on the 326-acre tract of land some 30 miles northwest of Soldier Field, with restaurants, retail and more on the property -- all for about $5 billion, with some taxpayer help.\n\nThe Bears had said they would pay for the stadium in Arlington Heights, with taxpayer dollars covering infrastructure costs such as roads and sewers. Those plans stalled, with the team citing a property assessment it said was too high.\n\nThey would remain tenants by staying in Chicago rather than owning a stadium in Arlington Heights. But Warren said he sees it as more of a partnership with the city rather than a landlord-tenant relationship.\n\n\"I believe in Mayor Johnson,\" Warren said. \"I believe in his staff, his vision, I believe in this city. I don't look at it as being a renter. I look at it as being able to develop a relationship, to be able to come together. People asked that same question in Minnesota -- why would you want to be a renter?\"\n\nAssociated Press reporter Sophia Tareen in Chicago contributed to this report. ___\n\nAP NFL: {"uri": "8096673957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:55:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:55:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:55:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2024/apr/25/chicago-bears-new-stadium-public-funding-soldier-field", "title": "Chicago Bears to seek public funding in $5bn plan for new lakefront stadium", "body": "Bears unveil $5bn proposal for new domed lakefront stadiumPlan calls for $900m from Illinois Sports Facilities Authority\n\nThe Chicago Bears unveiled a nearly $5bn proposal Wednesday for an enclosed stadium next door to their current home at Soldier Field as part of a major project that would transform the city's lakefront, and they are asking for public funding to help make it happen.\n\nThe plan calls for $3.2bn for the new stadium plus an additional $1.5bn in infrastructure. The team and the city said the project would add green and open space while improving access to the city's Museum Campus and could also include a publicly owned hotel.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said.\n\nThe announcement at Soldier Field comes during a busy week for the Bears. They are expected to take 2022 Heisman Trophy winner Caleb Williams with the No 1 pick in the draft on Thursday night and bank on the USC quarterback to solidify a position that has long been a sore spot for the founding NFL franchise.\n\nThe team said last month it was prepared to provide more than $2bn in funding toward a publicly owned stadium in the city.\n\nThe proposal calls for $2.025bn from the Bears, $300m from an NFL loan and $900m in bonds from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority. The funding from the ISFA would involve extending bonds of the existing 2% hotel tax.\n\nThe Bears said the project would generate $8bn in economic impact for the region. It would be built in three phases and take up to five years. The new stadium would be constructed on a parking lot just south of Soldier Field, the Bears' home since 1971. The team's lease at the 100-year-old stadium runs through 2033.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson gave a full-throated endorsement, saying the project is in line with Daniel Burnham's \"Plan of Chicago\". He said there would be no tax hikes or new taxes for Chicago residents.\n\nRenderings show the Bears' stadium would have a translucent roof and massive glass panels that would bring in sunlight and allow for views of Chicago's famed skyline. The plan is to host major concerts throughout the year as well as Super Bowls, Final Fours and Big Ten championship games.\n\nThough Soldier Field's famed colonnades would be preserved, the spaceship-like stadium that was installed in the renovation two decades ago would be torn out and replaced by playing fields as well as park space. The plan calls for a pedestrian mall, food and beverage options, a promenade and plaza.\n\n\"My administration insisted that any new project - especially one on public land - must deliver strong public benefit and public use for the City of Chicago, and I am pleased today that this plan does exactly that,\" Johnson said.\n\nIllinois governor JB Pritzker, however, said he wasn't on board.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal and I wonder whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker told reporters Wednesday at an unrelated news conference. \"I'm not sure this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nIllinois' top legislative leaders were also doubtful.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Illinois house speaker Emanuel 'Chris' Welch said at an unrelated news conference. \"There is no environment for something like this today.\"\n\nHowever, he added that the environment in Springfield does change.\n\nThe proposal comes as two other Chicago sports teams, including the White Sox and Red Stars, have expressed interest in public funding for new stadiums.\n\nWarren, who replaced the retired Ted Phillips a year ago, played a role in the construction of US Bank Stadium in Minneapolis through a public-private partnership when he worked in the Minnesota Vikings' front office from 2005 to 2019.\n\nThe Bears spent $197.2m more than a year ago to purchase the site of the shuttered Arlington International Racecourse from Churchill Downs Inc. They envisioned building a stadium on the 326-acre tract of land some 30 miles northwest of Soldier Field, with restaurants, retail and more on the property - all for about $5bn, with some taxpayer help.\n\nThe Bears had said they would pay for the stadium in Arlington Heights, with taxpayer dollars covering infrastructure costs such as roads and sewers. Those plans stalled, with the team citing a property assessment it said was too high.\n\nThey would remain tenants by staying in Chicago rather than owning a stadium in Arlington Heights. But Warren said he sees it as more of a partnership with the city rather than a landlord-tenant relationship.\n\n\"I believe in Mayor Johnson,\" Warren said. \"I believe in his staff, his vision, I believe in this city. I don't look at it as being a renter. I look at it as being able to develop a relationship, to be able to come together. People asked that same question in Minnesota - why would you want to be a renter?\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8095130687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:51:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:51:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:51:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/live-watch-the-chicago-bears-announcement-on-new-stadium-plans-in-the-city/3419131/", "title": "LIVE: Watch the Chicago Bears' announcement on new stadium plans in the city Wednesday", "body": "The announcement, set to take place at 12 p.m., will be made \"in collaboration with city officials and stakeholders\" at the Bears' current home, Soldier Field, the team said in a press release\n\nThe Chicago Bears will make a big announcement Wednesday as they reveal some of their first plans for a new, \"state-of-the-art, publicly owned enclosed stadium\" along Chicago's lakefront.\n\nThe announcement, set to take place at 12 p.m., will be made \"in collaboration with city officials and stakeholders\" at the Bears' current home, Soldier Field, the team said in a press release. The Bears said they will also announce plans for green and open space along the lakefront, with preserved access to the shoreline for families on the Museum Campus, according to the release.\n\nThe press conference will be streamed live in the player above once it begins.\n\nAccording to a report from the Chicago Tribune, the stadium would cost approximately $4.6 billion to build, with taxpayers financing roughly half of the cost.\n\nAfter purchasing land in suburban Arlington Heights for a proposed domed stadium, the team recently changed course and committed to building in Chicago, setting their sights on a \"publicly-owned\" stadium on the city's lakefront, located near their current home at Soldier Field.\n\nThe move could be seen as an attempt to ease concerns from preservation group Friends of the Parks, which successfully sued to prevent George Lucas from building a museum along the lakefront and has previously voiced opposition to the construction of any new stadium project on Museum Campus.\n\nFriends of the Parks declined comment ahead of the Bears' announced press conference.\n\nThe Bears' plans have also faced increased scrutiny amid a separate push from the Chicago White Sox to secure public funding for a stadium project in the South Loop. According to a recent Crain's report, the teams have been told that there is little appetite on the part of lawmakers to approve separate financing plans for stadiums, and urged the two teams to work together.\n\nThe Bears have pledged up to $2 billion in private funding for a stadium, but have not announced other financing details ahead of Wednesday's press conference.\n\nThe Bears must overcome several obstacles to make the domed stadium on the lakefront a reality.\n\nThe first is ensuring a healthy, long-term relationship between the team and the park district. Given their rocky history, that bridge might be harder to cross than it sounds.\n\n\"I believe in people, I believe in relationships,\" Warren said about the park district-team relationship. \"And even since I've been able to be here and spend time with individuals at Soldier Field, individuals at the park district, individuals in the city of Chicago, I've only been welcomed. And we've had a great relationship. And I think people have seen that. They feel it. And I'm just confident that when you have a common goal that people can focus on and come together, I'm confident that we'll have a positive relationship as we go forward. And so one of the things I promised myself when I started on April 17 of last year was that I was going to understand and appreciate and embrace the history of the Chicago Bears and all the relationships. But any tension or negativity, I was not going to take it forward.\n\nMORE: Bears' new stadium plan raises funding questions as taxpayers still owe $589M on Soldier Field\n\n\"And so I started from scratch. And I feel that we have not only great from a business relationship, but we've developed a personal relationship. And we work together very well. So I'm pleased with the way that it's gone. And I look forward to even building stronger relationships in the future. So that's an area that's not really a concern of mine.\"\n\nAs far as the thought that the lakefront project would require more than $1 billion in public infrastructure investment, Warren views the investment, whatever the number is, as good for the city of Chicago as it looks to compete against other cities in the marketplace.\n\n\"Those are things that we're working on. And one thing that I can guarantee you, I am fiscally conservative, and I am financially responsible,\" Warren said when asked about public funding. \"So anything that we recommend, from a financial standpoint, will be very well thought out.\"\n\nWarren cited a Sports Business Journal article that did not have Chicago in \"Top 25 Sports Business Cities\" as evidence that the investment is needed.\n\n\"But to think Chicago, you know, with this massive background, all the professional sports teams we have, the beautiful landscape, the topography, all those things involved, known for an incredible sports city. For us not to be on that list, from a business standpoint, those are the things that as a citizen of downtown Chicago and the state of Illinois, those are things from a business standpoint, concern me I look forward to the day that events like [the NFL league meetings] should and can be and will be held in downtown Chicago.\"\n\nBears President Kevin Warren recently discussed the change of direction in the team's plans during media availabilities at the NFL league meetings in Orlando.\n\nWhen asked about the Bears' pivot to the lakefront and the steam their plan is gaining, Warren noted there is still a long way to go, but he believes things are moving in the right direction.\n\n\"All of these projects are, you know, that's a great word. They require momentum. They require vision,\" Warren said. \"They require tenacity. They require a lot of thought and planning, but they also require momentum. And I strongly believe that we're building momentum to that museum area.\n\n\"So when you have that combination of the museum, the lakefront, the beach, the architecture, and most of all, what makes Chicago special is the people. And so when you can mix that together, you do get great momentum, but it's going to require a lot of work as we proceed forward.\"\n\nWarren and the Bears are happy to own the Arlington Park property, but their sights are set on downtown.\n\n\"We are the largest landowner in Arlington Heights right now. 326 acres,\" Warren said. \"We own a beautiful piece of land. And I have great respect for Mayor Hayes and Randy Recklaus and all of the politicians there. My belief right now, these projects are incredibly difficult. And just learning the various things that I did in Minnesota, you have to be laser-focused. And right now, we're putting our energy to downtown Chicago, to the museum campus, just from an energy and resource standpoint. So we still own the land. We're the largest landowner. We'll stay in communication with Arlington Heights, but the focus now has to be on Chicago to give us the best opportunity for success.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8095699226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:28:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/sports/2024/04/bears-unveil-elaborate-plans-for-46b-domed-stadium-on-chicagos-lake-michigan-waterfront.html", "title": "Bears unveil elaborate plans for $4.6B domed stadium on Chicago's Lake Michigan waterfront", "body": "The Bears have unveiled more detailed plans to build a new stadium on Lake Michigan.\n\nOfficials from the team, city and state gathered for a public presentation on Wednesday in which they expanded on announced plans for a domed stadium and community gathering place.\n\nThe Bears are hoping to build 4.6 billion stadium development in a parking lot area south of Soldier Field in ther city's Museum Campus that would also include 14 acres of athletic fields and green park space, an ice-skating rink in winter and potential developments like a sports culture museum or publicly owned hotel.\n\nThe plan calls for $3.2 billion for the new stadium plus an additional $1.5 billion in infrastructure.\n\nThe Bears would continue to play at Soldier Field, the oldest stadium in the NFL, until the project is completed via three phases, the last of which would conclude in summer 2028. Construction would begin in summer 2025.\n\n\"The Bears have been proud to call Chicago home for more than 100 years. Perhaps no other sports team embodies the character of the city it represents better than the Bears and Chicago,\" said chairman George H. McCaskey. \"Our founder, George Halas, emphasized the importance of being a champion for Chicago. This has been part of the foundation of our organization. That is why we are excited to invest in the greatest city in the world through a stadium project and site improvements that will benefit Chicagoans and visitors.\"\n\nThe new stadium would feature a translucent roof and large window with view of Chicago's skyline, similar to features seen at Sofi Stadium in Inglewood or U.S. Bank in Minnesota, but Soldier Field's famed colonnades would be preserved, the team said.\n\nThe Bears have committed $2 billion toward the project, but would need additional funding in the form of a $300 million loan from the NFL Stadium program and $900 million from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which involve extending bonds of an existing 2% hotel tax.\n\nIn addition to NFL games, it would host events like concerts year-round and be an option for Super Bowls, college basketball's Final Four and soccer.\n\nOfficials say the stadium project would create 43,000 construction jobs and have an $8.4 billion impact during construction. Once built it would create 4,000 permanent jobs and an ongoing $455 million economic impact, officials said.\n\n\"This is a beautiful day for the city of Chicago. It really is,\" Mayor Brandon Johnson said. \"As a lifelong Bears fan, it is an honor to be here to celebrate the Bears commitment to remaining the Chicago Bears. Any new development project on the lakefront has to have real private investment, real public use and real economic participation for the entire city. Today's announcement delivers on all three.\"\n\nThere remains some notable skeptics of the proposal, though. Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker, who was not present at the press conference, said Wednesday that he doesn't see why taxpayers should foot the bill for a significant portion of the project.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal, and I wonder whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker said, via the Chicago Tribune. \"There are a lot of priorities that the state has, and I'm not sure that this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nIllinois' top legislative leaders also expressed doubt.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Illinois House Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch said, according to the Associated Press. \"There is no environment for something like this today.\"\n\nThe Bears have called Soldier Field home since 1971, but it is the smallest stadium in the NFL, with a capacity of 61,500. The team's current lease runs through 2033.\n\nSeveral NFL teams have left city centers for the suburbs in recent years including the New York Giants and New York Jets, San Francisco 49ers, Dallas Cowboys and Washington Commanders.\n\n\"We feel that the time is now,\" Bears President Kevin Warren said, noting that the longer it takes for decisions to be made, the more expensive the project will become.\n\nThe team had previously purchased 326 acres of racetrack property in Arlington Heights for $197.2 million but have not begun developing the site, citing a property assessment it said was too high, the Associated Press reported.", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mlive"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SoFi_Stadium", {"uri": "8094701750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:35:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:35:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/chicago-bears-to-announce-plans-for-new-state-of-the-art-stadium-along-the-lakefront/3418927/", "title": "Chicago Bears to announce plans for new, 'state-of-the-art' stadium along the lakefront", "body": "The Bears have pledged up to $2 billion in private funding for a stadium. Reports say taxpayers would be on the hook for the rest\n\nA day before the NFL Draft is set to begin, the Chicago Bears, \"in collaboration with city officials and stakeholders,\" are scheduled Wednesday to announce plans for a new, \"state-of-the-art, publicly owned enclosed stadium\" along the city's lakefront, the team said in a press release.\n\nThe Bears said they will also announce plans for green and open space along the lakefront, with preserved access to the shoreline for families on the Museum Campus, according to the release.\n\nAccording to a report from the Chicago Tribune, the stadium would cost approximately $4.6 billion to build, with taxpayers financing roughly half of the cost.\n\nThe announcement will take place at 12 p.m. Wednesday at the Bears' current home, Soldier Field. It will be streamed in the player above once it begins.\n\nAfter purchasing land in suburban Arlington Heights for a proposed domed stadium, the team recently changed course and committed to building in Chicago, setting their sights on a \"publicly-owned\" stadium on the city's lakefront, located near their current home at Soldier Field.\n\nThe move could be seen as an attempt to ease concerns from preservation group Friends of the Parks, which successfully sued to prevent George Lucas from building a museum along the lakefront and has previously voiced opposition to the construction of any new stadium project on Museum Campus.\n\nFriends of the Parks declined comment ahead of the Bears' announced press conference.\n\nThe Bears' plans have also faced increased scrutiny amid a separate push from the Chicago White Sox to secure public funding for a stadium project in the South Loop. According to a recent Crain's report, the teams have been told that there is little appetite on the part of lawmakers to approve separate financing plans for stadiums, and urged the two teams to work together.\n\nThe Bears have pledged up to $2 billion in private funding for a stadium, but have not announced other financing details ahead of Wednesday's press conference.\n\nBears President Kevin Warren recently discussed the change of direction in the team's plans during media availabilities at the NFL league meetings in Orlando.\n\nWhen asked about the Bears' pivot to the lakefront and the steam their plan is gaining, Warren noted there is still a long way to go, but he believes things are moving in the right direction.\n\n\"All of these projects are, you know, that's a great word. They require momentum. They require vision,\" Warren said. \"They require tenacity. They require a lot of thought and planning, but they also require momentum. And I strongly believe that we're building momentum to that museum area.\n\n\"So when you have that combination of the museum, the lakefront, the beach, the architecture, and most of all, what makes Chicago special is the people. And so when you can mix that together, you do get great momentum, but it's going to require a lot of work as we proceed forward.\"\n\nWarren and the Bears are happy to own the Arlington Park property, but their sights are set on downtown.\n\n\"We are the largest landowner in Arlington Heights right now. 326 acres,\" Warren said. \"We own a beautiful piece of land. And I have great respect for Mayor Hayes and Randy Recklaus and all of the politicians there. My belief right now, these projects are incredibly difficult. And just learning the various things that I did in Minnesota, you have to be laser-focused. And right now, we're putting our energy to downtown Chicago, to the museum campus, just from an energy and resource standpoint. So we still own the land. We're the largest landowner. We'll stay in communication with Arlington Heights, but the focus now has to be on Chicago to give us the best opportunity for success.\"\n\nThe Bears must overcome several obstacles to make the domed stadium on the lakefront a reality.\n\nThe first is ensuring a healthy, long-term relationship between the team and the park district. Given their rocky history, that bridge might be harder to cross than it sounds.\n\n\"I believe in people, I believe in relationships,\" Warren said about the park district-team relationship. \"And even since I've been able to be here and spend time with individuals at Soldier Field, individuals at the park district, individuals in the city of Chicago, I've only been welcomed. And we've had a great relationship. And I think people have seen that. They feel it. And I'm just confident that when you have a common goal that people can focus on and come together, I'm confident that we'll have a positive relationship as we go forward. And so one of the things I promised myself when I started on April 17 of last year was that I was going to understand and appreciate and embrace the history of the Chicago Bears and all the relationships. But any tension or negativity, I was not going to take it forward.\n\nMORE: Bears' new stadium plan raises funding questions as taxpayers still owe $589M on Soldier Field\n\n\"And so I started from scratch. And I feel that we have not only great from a business relationship, but we've developed a personal relationship. And we work together very well. So I'm pleased with the way that it's gone. And I look forward to even building stronger relationships in the future. So that's an area that's not really a concern of mine.\"\n\nAs far as the thought that the lakefront project would require more than $1 billion in public infrastructure investment, Warren views the investment, whatever the number is, as good for the city of Chicago as it looks to compete against other cities in the marketplace.\n\n\"Those are things that we're working on. And one thing that I can guarantee you, I am fiscally conservative, and I am financially responsible,\" Warren said when asked about public funding. \"So anything that we recommend, from a financial standpoint, will be very well thought out.\"\n\nWarren cited a Sports Business Journal article that did not have Chicago in \"Top 25 Sports Business Cities\" as evidence that the investment is needed.\n\n\"But to think Chicago, you know, with this massive background, all the professional sports teams we have, the beautiful landscape, the topography, all those things involved, known for an incredible sports city. For us not to be on that list, from a business standpoint, those are the things that as a citizen of downtown Chicago and the state of Illinois, those are things from a business standpoint, concern me I look forward to the day that events like [the NFL league meetings] should and can be and will be held in downtown Chicago.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC {"uri": "8096662567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:47:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:47:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:47:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/2978956/chicago-bears-look-for-public-financing-in-building-a-new-stadium/", "title": "Chicago Bears look for public financing in building a new stadium - Washington Examiner", "body": "(The Center Square) - The Chicago Bears on Wednesday unveiled details about a proposed new stadium complex on the lakefront in which the NFL team will seek taxpayer funding, something that is not sitting well with Illinois' governor and legislative leaders.\n\nThe team is planning to build a state-of-the-art, domed lakefront stadium near Soldier Field, its current stadium. The Bears said they'd provide over $2 billion for the project, which they said would cover over 70% of the costs. But projections put the total price tag at around $4.7 billion.\n\nThe Bears said the project would create 43,000 temporary construction jobs and generate $8 billion in economic impact. Such economic impact numbers provided by other major professional sports teams have been challenged and often debunked in other regions of the country.\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson was on hand with the Bears for the announcement and said the stadium complex could host numerous events.\n\n\"Including Chicago Public School championships, graduations, major concerts, the Final Four, Big Ten Championship, my next inauguration, I don't know, we will just keep adding to it,\" said Johnson.\n\nRevealed at a news conference Wednesday, the Chicago Bears show a promotional video, feature Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, and details about the cost of a proposed stadium. At a separate event, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker and House Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch, D-Hillside, react. Chicago Bears, Illinois.gov\n\nAt an unrelated event Wednesday, Gov. J.B. Pritzker was asked about the prospect of taxpayers helping build a new stadium.\n\n\"I just think that the taxpayers' dollars need to be protected and I think it's my job to be a good steward of those dollars,\" said Pritzker.\n\nSenate President Don Harmon, D-Oak Park, issued a statement regarding the Chicago Bears' stadium proposal.\n\n\"At first glance, more than $2 billion in private funding is better than zero and a more credible opening offer,\" said Harmon. \"But there's an obvious, substantial gap remaining, and I echo the governor's skepticism.\"\n\nTo make the plan a reality, the Bears want the Illinois General Assembly to approve $1.5 billion in new bonding for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nHouse Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch, D-Hillside, said the request would have little chance.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Welch said. \"There's no environment for something like this today.\"\n\nTaxpayers still owe more than $600 million for past renovations of Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, whose occupants, the White Sox, also are looking to build a new stadium with help from taxpayers.\n\nThe Bears purchased the former Arlington National Racecourse property for a possible site for a new stadium, but negotiations fell through. Arlington Heights officials said they will be ready and waiting if the Bears change their minds.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "none@washingtonexaminer.com", "name": "none", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Bears", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago Bears"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. officials have been invited to a news conference on Wednesday to announce plans for the construction of a new domed stadium on the lakefront.\n\nDetails about the plans are limited, and it is currently unclear how the proposed stadium would be funded, but sources told WGN-TV that it would be publicly owned.\n\nIt is the latest development in the ongoing saga involving the Chicago Bears stadium.\n\nIf the team moves forward with the new plans, it would put an end to the prospect of the Bears moving to the site of the former Arlington International Racecourse, which was purchased by {"uri": "8093743456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "20:35:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T20:35:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T20:35:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/04/23/skeptics-await-details-of-chicago-bears-lakefront-stadium-plan/", "title": "Skeptics await details of Chicago Bears' lakefront stadium plan", "body": "The Chicago Bears are set to announce their plans for a new enclosed stadium on the lakefront with taxpayer help -- but the team will have to overcome serious skepticism from several directions.\n\nThe Bears have proposed $2 billion in private spending for a publicly owned stadium just south of their current home at Soldier Field. The 100-year-old stadium would be torn down to make way.\n\nAt a much-anticipated news conference at noon Wedneday, officials are expected to lay out plans for a stadium with increased open space and improved access and with potential add-ons that could include a hotel and sports museum.\n\nThe team must answer two crucial questions: who would pay for the rest of the project, and how? Sports consultant Marc Ganis has estimated stadium construction costs at $2.5 billion to $3 billion, plus an estimated $1 billion in associated infrastructure.\n\nThe team has discussed extending the current 2% city hotel tax that is committed to pay for past renovations at Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, the White Sox ballpark. The Sox also are looking for help to build a new stadium in the South Loop.\n\nBut the hotel tax has fallen far short of paying off the existing debt. As a result, taxpayers still owe $629 million for past renovations of Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate.\n\nThen there is the question of whether the Bears can legally build on the site. The city's Lakefront Protection ordinance calls for public use of the lakefront, and the team has called for public ownership of the stadium.\n\nThe non-profit Friends of the Parks opposes building a new stadium for a privately owned team on the lakefront. The group successfully drove \"Star Wars\" creator George Lucas away from plans to build a movie art museum on the same site, now used for parking lots.\n\nWhatever the Bears propose, they will have to win over skeptics, including Gov. J.B. Pritzker. The governor called the Bears' proposed investment \"a good first step,\" and said he's willing to listen to their proposal, but said it shouldn't be a priority for the state.\n\nJoe Ferguson, president of the Civic Federation, a fiscal watchdog group, told the Tribune in a recent interview that the Bears and Sox need to show vetted cost and revenue projections.\n\n\"Everybody wants to keep the teams (in the city) -- the question is, on what terms?\" he said. \"There's not a lot of information necessary to say one of these (plans) actually is viable, or whether it's a way to take us to the cleaners when we're already carrying hundreds of millions of dollars of debt for the last time we did something like this.\"\n\nThe city recently went through a similar scenario, he said, when it chose the Bally's casino for development, only to find the project is already being scaled back and has funding issues.\n\n\"I think Gov. Pritzker has spoken to this exactly right, with a real wariness about public funding of sports stadiums,\" Ferguson said. \"We need to see reliable, thorough revenue projections for this before we can even open the conversation.\"\n\nMaking the situation more precarious, Ferguson said, is that all levels of government are facing financial cliffs in multiple areas -- pensions, transit, and Chicago Public Schools, with the end of billions of dollars in federal COVID pandemic money.\n\nThe Bears are offering a $2 billion as a big incentive to do business with them. But if the city pays $1 billion toward the plan, sports economist J.C. Bradbury said, voicing a common concern among economists, that's $1 billion that would be better spent on other public projects, or returned to taxpayers.\n\n\"Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice shame on me,\" Bradbury said. \"The Bears aren't going to leave one of the most iconic football markets in the country. Tell the Bears to pay for their own damn stadium, and if they don't like it, to go jump in Lake Michigan.\"\n\nThe team has taken a long, strange trip to get to this point. In 2022, officials agreed to buy the former Arlington International Racecourse for $197 million, closing on the deal last year. Under prior president and CEO Ted Phillips, the team made an elaborate presentation of its plans for a $5 billion mixed-used development on the 326-acre site, with an enclosed stadium, housing and entertainment.\n\nBut since Kevin Warren became team president and CEO last year, the team has been unable to reach agreement over property taxes with local schools in the Arlington Heights area.\n\nAs the Minnesota Vikings did when Warren was an executive there, the Bears reversed course from a suburban stadium site to downtown. Warren has extolled the beauty and energy of the city, talked of his rapport with Mayor Brandon Johnson, and has said the lakefront is the \"ideal location.\"\n\n\"Absolutely we can build something that would be magnificent downtown,\" he said.\n\nThe team wouldn't necessarily have to move right away, with a lease at Soldier Field through 2033. But Warren has talked about the importance of momentum in getting the stadium project done. State lawmakers are scheduled to meet until May 24, then have a veto session in the fall, and a brief lame-duck session in the new year.\n\nReconstructing the museum campus around a new Bears stadium could help attract new residential and retail development along the lakefront, replacing some of the tax revenue lost by the declining property values of downtown office towers, said Eric Feinberg, vice chairman and co-head of the Chicago region for Savills, a commercial real estate firm.\n\nIf the Bears' proposal improves lakefront access with better public transportation with new gathering spaces, it's possible the new stadium district will attract families year-round, not just on a handful of Sundays.\n\nFeinberg said he still doesn't understand why the Bears didn't settle disagreements with Arlington Heights' officials before buying the former Churchill Downs site.\n\n\"It seems so strange they would plop down all this money, and then say this is just not working out for us,\" he said. \"It boggles my mind.\"\n\nIf the Bears do cut a deal for a lakefront stadium, it would leave Arlington Heights with a big hole to fill, said John Melaniphy of Melaniphy & Associates, a former business and development coordinator for the village of Arlington Heights. But even without football, the former racetrack site could still attract mixed-use developments with apartments, restaurants and entertainment.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "robert_mccoppin@chicagotribune.com", "name": "Robert McCoppin", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "brian_j_rogal@chicagotribune.com", "name": "Brian J. {"uri": "8094101038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "03:33:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T03:33:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T03:32:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/report-taxpayers-would-cover-half-of-proposed-bears-lakefront-stadium/", "title": "Report: Taxpayers would cover half of proposed Bears lakefront stadium", "body": "The Chicago Bears are set to usher in a new era of football this week during the 2024 NFL Draft, but they're also trying to do the same when it comes to their new stadium. The team is set to announce plans for a new lakefront stadium on Wednesday, and details about the project have started to surface.\n\nAccording to the Chicago Tribune, the Bears' plan to build a new stadium will cost approximately $4.6 billion, with half of that coming from taxpayers. The actual enclosed stadium would cost around $3.2 billion, and the other $1.4 billion would be used for improvements to the infrastructure. All of this and more is expected to be announced at noon CT on Wednesday during a press conference with the Bears and the city of Chicago.\n\nWhile the plans may be getting underway, the Bears may have a hard time pulling this off for a number of reasons. They will need to get state officials on board with the plan, and they haven't shown much interest in either the Bears or the White Sox, who are also requesting money for a new Chicago stadium. It's worth noting that Chicago taxpayers are still on the hook for approximately $629 million for the Soldier Field renovations and the building of Guaranteed Rate Field back in the early 2000s. The Bears will also need to win over the \"Friends of the Park\" nonprofit organization, which has already come out against building a new stadium just south of Soldier Field.\n\nThese impending plans are the latest pivot in the never-ending stadium saga that began with the Bears entering into an agreement to purchase 326 acres of land in Arlington Heights nearly three years ago. Since then, the twists and turns, including the change in leadership from Ted Phillips to Kevin Warren, have landed the team back in a position where they're looking to stay in the city.\n\nWednesday's press conference will hopefully answer plenty of questions. The $3.2 billion price tag for the stadium alone certainly raises eyebrows, though. It would be the second-most expensive NFL stadium in the country, according to Rob Schwarz Jr. of Bear Goggles On. As for the $2.3 billion taxpayers would owe, fans and residents of Chicago aren't loving the idea.", "source": {"uri": "bearswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bears Wire"}, "authors": {"uri": "8092143456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "22:04:25", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T22:04:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T22:04:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/chicago-bears-to-announce-lakefront-stadium-plans-this-week/3417365/", "title": "Chicago Bears to announce lakefront stadium plans this week", "body": "The Chicago Bears will unveil plans this week for a proposed state-of-the-art stadium along Chicago's lakefront, the team announced Monday.\n\nAccording to a press release, the Bears, \"in collaboration with city officials and stakeholders,\" will unveil the plans Wednesday, just one day before the start of the NFL Draft.\n\nAfter purchasing land in suburban Arlington Heights for a proposed domed stadium, the team has changed course and is now intent on pursuing a \"publicly-owned\" stadium on the city's lakefront, located near their current home at Soldier Field.\n\nIn addition to the stadium, the Bears say they will also announce plans for green and open space along the lakefront, with preserved access to the shoreline for families on the Museum Campus, according to the release.\n\nBears President Kevin Warren recently discussed the change of direction in the team's plans during media availabilities at the NFL league meetings in Orlando.\n\nWarren's 30-minute sit-down with the Chicago media mainly focused on the Bears' efforts to build a new stadium on the lakefront, as opposed to the Arlington Heights location.\n\nListen to Kevin Warren's full press conference\n\nWhen asked about the Bears' pivot to the lakefront and the steam their plan is gaining, Warren noted there is still a long way to go, but he believes things are moving in the right direction.\n\n\"All of these projects are, you know, that's a great word. They require momentum. They require vision,\" Warren said. \"They require tenacity. They require a lot of thought and planning, but they also require momentum. And I strongly believe that we're building momentum to that museum area.\n\n\"So when you have that combination of the museum, the lakefront, the beach, the architecture, and most of all, what makes Chicago special is the people. And so when you can mix that together, you do get great momentum, but it's going to require a lot of work as we proceed forward.\"\n\nWarren and the Bears are happy to own the Arlington Park property, but their sights are set on downtown.\n\n\"We are the largest landowner in Arlington Heights right now. 326 acres,\" Warren said. \"We own a beautiful piece of land. And I have great respect for Mayor Hayes and Randy Recklaus and all of the politicians there. My belief right now, these projects are incredibly difficult. And just learning the various things that I did in Minnesota, you have to be laser-focused. And right now, we're putting our energy to downtown Chicago, to the museum campus, just from an energy and resource standpoint. So we still own the land. We're the largest landowner. We'll stay in communication with Arlington Heights, but the focus now has to be on Chicago to give us the best opportunity for success.\"\n\nWarren doesn't view the change of focus as a waste of the Bears' initial investment in the Arlington Park property.\n\n\"I think one of the things that I would say, and especially in my position, is I always have to live in a world of prioritization,\" Warren said. \"So it's good to own land. And at the appropriate time, we'll address what is the best use of that land. But for now, the energy and the efforts of our individuals internally, with our consultants and ownership, is focused on Chicago.\"\n\nThe Bears must overcome several obstacles to make the domed stadium on the lakefront a reality.\n\nThe first is ensuring a healthy, long-term relationship between the team and the park district. Given their rocky history, that bridge might be harder to cross than it sounds.\n\n\"I believe in people, I believe in relationships,\" Warren said about the park district-team relationship. \"And even since I've been able to be here and spend time with individuals at Soldier Field, individuals at the park district, individuals in the city of Chicago, I've only been welcomed. And we've had a great relationship. And I think people have seen that. They feel it. And I'm just confident that when you have a common goal that people can focus on and come together, I'm confident that we'll have a positive relationship as we go forward. And so one of the things I promised myself when I started on April 17 of last year was that I was going to understand and appreciate and embrace the history of the Chicago Bears and all the relationships. But any tension or negativity, I was not going to take it forward.\n\n\"And so I started from scratch. And I feel that we have not only great from a business relationship, but we've developed a personal relationship. And we work together very well. So I'm pleased with the way that it's gone. And I look forward to even building stronger relationships in the future. So that's an area that's not really a concern of mine.\"\n\nAs far as the thought that the lakefront project would require more than $1 billion in public infrastructure investment, Warren views the investment, whatever the number is, as good for the city of Chicago as it looks to compete against other cities in the marketplace.\n\n\"Those are things that we're working on. And one thing that I can guarantee you, I am fiscally conservative, and I am financially responsible,\" Warren said when asked about public funding. \"So anything that we recommend, from a financial standpoint, will be very well thought out.\"\n\nWarren cited a Sports Business Journal article that did not have Chicago in \"Top 25 Sports Business Cities\" as evidence that the investment is needed.\n\n\"But to think Chicago, you know, with this massive background, all the professional sports teams we have, the beautiful landscape, the topography, all those things involved, known for an incredible sports city. For us not to be on that list, from a business standpoint, those are the things that as a citizen of downtown Chicago and the state of Illinois, those are things from a business standpoint, concern me I look forward to the day that events like [the NFL league meetings] should and can be and will be held in downtown Chicago.\"\n\nThe Bears will also face resistance from Friends of the Park, a preservation group known for protecting the lakefront and parks in Chicago. Friends of the Park successfully sued to prevent George Lucas from building a museum along the lakefront and have been opposed to a new stadium on the museum campus.\n\nFriends of the Parks declined comment ahead of the Bears' announced press conference.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8092126039", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-22", "time": "21:41:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-22T21:41:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-22T21:41:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/04/22/chicago-bears-to-announce-plans-wednesday-for-new-domed-stadium-on-lakefront/", "title": "Chicago Bears to announce plans Wednesday for new domed stadium on lakefront", "body": "The Chicago Bears have set noon Wednesday to announce plans for a new domed stadium on the lakefront.\n\nTeam officials will make the announcement at Soldier Field, which would be demolished under the proposal.\n\nIn what will be a busy week for the team, the announcement will come one day before the Bears are scheduled to make the No. 1 pick in the NFL Draft.\n\nThe team said it plans to present a \"state-of-the-art, publicly owned enclosed stadium, along with additional green and open space with access to the lakefront for families and fans, on the Museum Campus.\"\n\nThe team has pledged to spend $2 billion in private money for the project. The cost of the stadium is estimated at $2.5 billion to $3 billion, plus $1 billion for associated roads and other infrastructure.\n\nThe crucial question is how any taxpayer cost would be funded, and whether city and state lawmakers would approve that. Taxpayers were still on the hook for $631 million for Soldier Field debt as of last year.\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson has said any deal must involve public benefit, and Gov. J.B. Pritzker has said he is not inclined to spend public money for a private business.\n\nThe new site would be on what are now parking lots just south of Soldier Field. The collonades from the old structure would be saved. The proposal is believed to potentially include a hotel and improved access to and from DuSable Lake Shore Drive.\n\nThe Bears bought the former Arlington International Racecourse in Arlington Heights for $197 million last year, and announce plans for a $5 billion mixed use development with a stadium, housing and entertainment. But the team switched focus back to Chicago this year after property tax negotiations with local school districts broke down.\n\nSeveral other communities, including Naperville and Aurora, also expressed interest in luring the Bears.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "robert_mccoppin@chicagotribune.com", "name": "Robert McCoppin", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soldier_Field", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Soldier Field"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Bears", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Chicago Bears"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Chicago", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Mayor of Chicago"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Campus", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Museum Campus"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandon,_Mississippi", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Brandon, Mississippi"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Brandon, Mississippi"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "J. "https://www.chicagotribune.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/CTC-L-Bears-stadium-Chicago-21_184358488_e28a1e.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9503122", "eventUri": "eng-9503122", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.01960784313725494, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8093979425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "01:10:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T01:10:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T01:10:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/taxpayers-would-pick-up-half-the-tab-for-bears-lakefront-stadium-sources-say/article_17ac2d3f-9b60-5bdd-8bb9-a24a5d77cce9.html", "title": "Taxpayers would pick up half the tab for Bears' lakefront stadium, sources say", "body": "CHICAGO -- The Chicago Bears are set to announce a $4.6 billion plan for a new enclosed stadium and lakefront area, half of which would come from taxpayers, sources said, but the team will have to overcome serious skepticism from several directions.\n\nThe stadium itself would cost $3.2 billion to build, with another $1.4 billion in proposed infrastructure improvements, according to sources familiar with the plan who spoke to the Chicago Tribune on the condition of anonymity.\n\nThe sources said the Bears plan to pledge $2.3 billion, which include some financing through the NFL. But the Bears' plan includes an additional $2.3 billion in public financing, along with refinancing outstanding debt for prior publicly financed stadium projects for the Bears and White Sox, according to the sources.\n\nTaxpayers would be on the hook for the proposed infrastructure improvements along with about $1 billion in new borrowing to finance the new stadium south of Soldier Field, the sources said.\n\nTo make the plan a reality, the Bears want the Illinois General Assembly to approve $1.5 billion in new bonding for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which carries the debt for prior projects at Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, sources said.\n\nAbout one-third of the new borrowing would be used to roll over existing stadium debt, and the plan calls for the new borrowing to be paid off over 40 years, which also would require legislative approval.\n\nSources said the Bears' plan calls for the debt to be repaid without raising the 2% hotel tax that currently goes to ISFA.\n\nThe details are expected to be revealed at a much-anticipated news conference at noon Wednesday where officials will lay out plans for the domed stadium with increased open space.\n\nThe 2% hotel tax has fallen far short of paying off the existing debt. As a result, taxpayers still owe $629 million for past renovations of Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, whose occupants, the White Sox, also are seeking a new stadium in the South Loop. To finance a new Bears stadium using the hotel tax, the state would have to increase the borrowing limit for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nThat could prove to be a tough sell in Springfield, however, where legislative leaders so far have given the Bears, and the Sox, a cool reception.\n\nThen there is the question of whether the Bears can legally build on the site. The city's lakefront protection ordinance calls for public use of the lakefront, and the team has called for public ownership of the stadium.\n\nThe nonprofit Friends of the Parks opposes building a stadium for a privately owned team on the lakefront. The group successfully drove \"Star Wars\" creator George Lucas away from plans to build a movie art museum on the same site, now used for parking lots.\n\nWhatever the Bears propose, they will have to win over skeptics, including Gov. J.B. Pritzker, who a spokesperson said Tuesday had not been briefed by the team about the stadium plans. The governor had previously called the Bears' proposed investment \"a good first step,\" and said he's willing to listen to their proposal, but said it shouldn't be a priority for the state.\n\nJoe Ferguson, president of the Civic Federation, a fiscal watchdog group, told the Tribune in a recent interview that the Bears and Sox need to show vetted cost and revenue projections.\n\n\"Everybody wants to keep the teams (in the city) -- the question is, on what terms?\" he said. \"There's not a lot of information necessary to say one of these (plans) actually is viable, or whether it's a way to take us to the cleaners when we're already carrying hundreds of millions of dollars of debt for the last time we did something like this.\"\n\nThe city recently went through a similar scenario, he said, when it chose the Bally's casino for development, only to find the project is already being scaled back and has funding issues.\n\n\"I think Gov. Pritzker has spoken to this exactly right, with a real wariness about public funding of sports stadiums,\" Ferguson said. \"We need to see reliable, thorough revenue projections for this before we can even open the conversation.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nMaking the situation more precarious, Ferguson said, is that all levels of government are facing financial cliffs in multiple areas -- pensions, transit and Chicago Public Schools -- with the end of billions of dollars in federal COVID-19 pandemic money.\n\nSports economist J.C. Bradbury, voicing a common concern among economists, said whatever public money is earmarked for the stadium would be better spent on other public projects, or returned to taxpayers.\n\n\"Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me,\" Bradbury said. \"The Bears aren't going to leave one of the most iconic football markets in the country. Tell the Bears to pay for their own damn stadium, and if they don't like it, to go jump in Lake Michigan.\"\n\nThe team has taken a long, strange trip to get to this point. In 2022, officials agreed to buy the former Arlington International Racecourse for $197 million, closing on the deal last year. Under prior President and CEO Ted Phillips, the team made an elaborate presentation of its plans for a $5 billion mixed-used development on the 326-acre site, with an enclosed stadium, housing and entertainment.\n\nBut since Kevin Warren became team president and CEO last year, the team has been unable to reach agreement over property taxes with local schools in the Arlington Heights area.\n\nAs the Minnesota Vikings did when Warren was an executive there, the Bears reversed course from a suburban stadium site to downtown. Warren has extolled the beauty and energy of the city, talked of his rapport with Mayor Brandon Johnson, and has said the lakefront is the \"ideal location.\"\n\n\"Absolutely we can build something that would be magnificent downtown,\" he said.\n\nThe team wouldn't necessarily have to move right away, with a lease at Soldier Field through 2033. But Warren has talked about the importance of momentum in getting the stadium project done. State lawmakers are scheduled to meet until May 24, then have a veto session in the fall, and a brief lame-duck session in the new year.\n\nReconstructing the museum campus around a new Bears stadium could help attract new residential and retail development along the lakefront, replacing some of the tax revenue lost by the declining property values of downtown office towers, said Eric Feinberg, vice chairman and co-head of the Chicago region for Savills, a commercial real estate firm.\n\nIf the Bears' proposal improves lakefront access with better public transportation with new gathering spaces, it's possible the new stadium district will attract families year-round, not just on a handful of Sundays.\n\nFeinberg said he still doesn't understand why the Bears didn't settle disagreements with Arlington Heights' officials before buying the former Churchill Downs site.\n\n\"It seems so strange they would plop down all this money, and then say this is just not working out for us,\" he said. \"It boggles my mind.\"\n\nIf the Bears do cut a deal for a lakefront stadium, it would leave Arlington Heights with a big hole to fill, said John Melaniphy of Melaniphy & Associates, a former business and development coordinator for the village of Arlington Heights. But even without football, the former racetrack site could still attract mixed-use developments with apartments, restaurants and entertainment.\n\n-- -- --\n\nChicago Tribune's Olivia Olander contributed.\n\n\u00a92024 Chicago Tribune. Visit chicagotribune.com.
