{"uri": "8095546748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:02:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:02:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:02:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/whats-bears-plan-control-traffic-195633260.html", "title": "What's the Bears' plan to control traffic to their new stadium?", "body": "A proposal for the Bears' new stadium Wednesday included increased capacity and hopes to become an entertainment hub in the country to host Super Bowls, Final Four games, etc.\n\nWith the increased capacity and usage, as opposed to Soldier Field, the Bears and the city of Chicago will surely run into traffic problems. Already, traffic problems exist with entering and exiting the lakefront campus; whether on foot or behind a wheel.\n\nWhat are the Bears' plans to address the increased traffic?\n\nBears newly appointed Chief Operating Officer Karen Murphy laid out the plan for traffic to the proposed stadium.\n\nThe first phase of the plan includes creating an \"improved interchange\" at 18th Street, which would become 19th Street on Lakeshore Drive. They're also looking at an entrance to the campus from the South to tie into their South parking lot.\n\nDouble-decking the South parking lot is also in the realm of possibilities.\n\nOn the North side, the Bears are looking to remove the light on Lakeshore Drive and McFetridge. They also hope to increase the space and accessibility on the lakefront path for pedestrians who are walking to the stadium.\n\nThe Bears estimate a 20% increase in campus capacity on the South side, with a 10-minute reduction in campus exit time. On the North side, they estimate a 50% increase in campus access --- likely because of the destruction of Soldier Field.\n\n\"If both these phases are done, this would be a 50% increase in lane capacity to the site, as well as a 20-minute reduction in exit times from our parking ramps, and 1,200 less hours daily for commuters on DuSable Lakeshore Drive,\" Murphy said during the presentation.\n\nMORE: How Bears plan to fund Chicago stadium project, and how much it will cost taxpayers\n\nAs far as financing this part of the stadium, it's not entirely clear, yet.\n\nThe team expects the entire stadium project to cost $4.7 billion: $3.2 for the stadium itself and just over $300 million for the infrastructure required to open it, then $1.2 billion for two other phases of development.\n\nThere wasn't a clear answer as to where the team would get the $300 million for the infrastructure. Murphy said the team is still working with the state and looking into different funding sources.\n\nIf the team gets the public funding needed to open the stadium, they said there will be two more phases of development requiring public money: one to maximize infrastructure for the stadium and surrounding campus totaling $510 million, and another phase for \"optional infrastructure to enhance the campus, improve circulation, and maximize public economic benefits,\" totaling $665 million. Add up all three phases plus the IFSA funding, and it's nearly $2.4 billion in public money.\n\nChicago mayor Brandon Johnson said on Wednesday that the Bears' new plan to build a stadium in Chicago will not raise taxes on city residents.\n\n\"I'm going to repeat that one more time to make sure that everybody gets it,\" Johnson said after the announcement. \"This project will result in no new {"uri": "8095704078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:34:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:34:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:34:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/why-bears-want-build-fixed-222318579.html", "title": "Why do Bears want to build fixed-roof dome? President shares new details explaining decision", "body": "Why do Bears want to build fixed-roof dome? President shares new details explaining decision originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nFor as long as the Bears have talked about new stadium plans, they've talked about their future stadium having a fixed roof. From former president Ted Phillips to current president Kevin Warren, from Arlington Heights to Chicago, building a domed stadium has been a constant. On Wednesday, Warren shared some more details on why the team will opt for a sealed dome rather than a retractable roof.\n\n\"That's another couple $100 million, and when we talked to organizations who had retractable roofs they said they used it maybe three or four times a year,\" Warren said. \"We tried to be fiscally responsible by building the stadium.\"\n\nWarren led the charge for the Vikings' U.S. Bank stadium project, which also has a fixed roof and pointed to that stadium, along with the Raiders' Allegiant Stadium and the Rams' SoFi Stadium as examples. Those stadiums are known for big, translucent windows to allow natural light to filter into the stadium. Warren said the proposed Bears stadium in Chicago would have the same, and offer views of the surrounding city.\n\n\"You'll feel like you're outdoors, that you may have to wear sunglasses,\" Warren said.\n\nThe renderings the Bears released are impressive looking, but Illinois lawmakers splashed water on the idea that they will come to pass for certain. Before the presentation began, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker said he was skeptical of the proposal to build a new publicly-owned stadium in the city.\n\n\"I wonder if it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker said. \"It's very important to me that, with all the state needs to accomplish, that we think about what the priorities are for the state... there are a lot of priorities the state has and I'm not sure that this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nAfter the presentation, Illinois Senate President Dan Harmon added his voice to the conversation.\n\n\"At first glance, more than $2 billion in private funding is better than zero and a more credible opening offer,\" Harmon said in a statement. \"But there's an obvious, substantial gap remaining, and I echo the governor's skepticism.\"\n\nPer the Bears presentation, they project their full stadium project will cost $4.7 billion. The team said it would contribute just over $2 billion, ask for $300 million from the NFL, and look to the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority for $900 million. That leaves a gap of about $1.5 billion, and the team would look for public money to make up the difference. Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson was emphatic in saying there would be no new taxes for Chicago residents. That seemingly leaves the team to look for state or federal dollars.\n\nThe Bears bought 326 acres of land in Arlington Heights last year, and previously announced plans to build a new stadium there. But contentious negotiations about property taxes in the suburbs have become an obstacle for that plan. {"uri": "2024-04-334348352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:10:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://theathletic.com/4207253/2023/02/15/chicago-bears-arlington-park-purchase/", "title": "Bears finalize purchase of Arlington Park property", "body": "The Chicago Bears finalized the purchase of Arlington Park property, the team announced Wednesday in an open letter. Here's what you need to know:\n\nHow we got here\n\nIn 1971, the Bears moved from Wrigley Field to Soldier Field to meet the NFL's requirements for seating capacity. Now, Soldier Field has the smallest capacity in the league (61,500).\n\nThe Bears have watched as team after team has built immaculate stadiums, and those franchises don't have to share revenue as a tenant in their building. As much as the McCaskeys treasure the tradition of Soldier Field, the NFL is a business, and the Bears are lagging behind the rest of the league when it comes to their stadium and making money off it. This has been inevitable. -- Fishbain\n\nMore work left to do\n\nAs the Bears said in their open letter, it's \"an important next step.\" But there is still a lot of work to do. The Bears' letter stressed that point while pitching the project as an opportunity for the region to host \"world-class entertainment and sporting events on an unprecedented scale.\" The job, though, now belongs to new team president and chief executive officer Kevin Warren -- and the Bears are extremely excited about that. Warren's resume includes the construction of the Vikings' U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis. It's one of the best stadiums in the NFL. \"When you land it like we did in Minnesota, you can feel it -- feel it every way,\" Warren said last month. -- Jahns\n\nDoes it make sense financially?\n\nIf building an NFL stadium is like running a marathon, the Bears just bought their running shoes. Next up? The expensive and difficult parts. Heck, the Bears might not even run this race.\n\nBy closing on their nearly $200 million deal to buy the 326-acre Arlington Park racetrack property, the Bears now have to move on to trying to finance the project, which is expected to cost billions of dollars. The Bears are touting this as one of the \"largest mega-projects in Midwest history.\" But can they find the money to get it done?\n\nThe organization is, of course, asking for public funding for the project. Getting the funding sorted out is the next step.\n\n\"If we construct a state-of-the-art stadium, we will not seek taxpayer funds locally or otherwise for the structure,\" the Bears wrote in their statement. \"If we proceed, however, this project would require assistance to ensure feasibility, including our securing property tax certainty and support for infrastructure commensurate with the public benefits the project will yield to the region.\" -- Greenberg\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n\"Last fall, we released an open letter confirming the team had reached an agreement for the purpose of acquiring 326 acres of property in Arlington Heights to secure the potential of beginning a new and exciting chapter for the Bears, our fans, the Chicagoland community, and the State of Illinois,\" the letter said. \"This week, we took another step toward realizing that vision by closing on the Arlington Park property.\"\n\n\"There is still a tremendous amount of due diligence work to be done to determine if constructing an enclosed state-of-the-art stadium and multi-purpose entertainment district is feasible.\"\n\nRequired reading", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8096409660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:16:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:16:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:16:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/sport/11184012/chicago-bears-stadium-soldier-field-nfl/", "title": "Inside Chicago Bears new $3.2 billion lakefront stadium", "body": "THE Chicago Bears have unveiled their plans to build a spectacular new stadium on the city's waterfront.\n\nThe $3.2 billion Burnham Park Project includes a new publicly-owned multipurpose replacement stadium for the Bears located just south of their legendary current home at Soldier Field.\n\nThe stadium is expected to hold 65,000 people, with a target of opening by 2028.\n\nThe Bears say the area will be used by the community all year long, with a park-based culture and focus on recreation.\n\nThe pictures show that the stadium will have stunning waterside views of the city.\n\n\"This is an incredibly, incredibly special day for the Chicago Bears,\" Bears President and CEO Kevin Warren said.\n\n\"For the City of Chicago, for the state of Illinois, for our ownership, for our players, for our coaches, for our staff members, for the alumni and for our incredible Chicago Bear fans.\n\n\"Today is about progress, and one of the things that I am most excited about today is the fact that this shows that in this city we have the intellectual capabilities, we have the heart, we have the passion, we have the foresight, we have the wisdom, we have the vision to do big things.\"\n\nAs they showed off images of the new venue on X, the site formerly known as Twitter, the Bears said, \"More than just a stadium.\n\n\"This project will provide Chicago families with a place to gather and play. A premier destination for the world's biggest sports and entertainment events.\"\n\nThe plans include 14 acres of athletic fields and park space to be used by the public and youth sports programs.\n\nThere will also be music concerts at the venue, particularly outside the months of the NFL season.\n\nThe Bears are keen for millions of people to benefit, with the fields set to be a safe place for the youth, including those from nearby underserved neighborhoods.\n\nSome fans have soon picked up on the potential issues however.\n\nThe biggest concern that has emerged seems to be over parking in what is a busy and condensed part of town.\n\n\"Where are we going to park and tailgate? {"uri": "8092278839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "01:19:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T01:19:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T01:18:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/chicago-bears-to-announce-plans-wednesday-for-new-domed-stadium-on-lakefront/article_5e5503ca-8947-5efc-8583-9014c1eb5ee4.html", "title": "Chicago Bears to announce plans Wednesday for new domed stadium on lakefront", "body": "Chicago Tribune\n\nThe Chicago Bears have set noon Wednesday to announce plans for a new domed stadium on the lakefront.\n\nTeam officials will make the announcement at Soldier Field, which would be demolished under the proposal.\n\nIn what will be a busy week for the team, the announcement will come one day before the Bears are scheduled to make the No. 1 pick in the NFL Draft.\n\nThe team said it plans to present a \"state-of-the-art, publicly owned enclosed stadium, along with additional green and open space with access to the lakefront for families and fans, on the Museum Campus.\"\n\nThe team has pledged to spend $2 billion in private money for the project. The cost of the stadium is estimated at $2.5 billion to $3 billion, plus $1 billion for associated roads and other infrastructure.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson Normal police investigating second shots-fired report in six hours Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Police: 2 arrested on weapons charges after shots fired in Bloomington Bloomington murder trial delayed as police search for witness Oberweis Dairy files for bankruptcy McLean Co. Sheriff's Office investigating after man found dead in Dry Grove Township\n\nThe crucial question is how any taxpayer cost would be funded, and whether city and state lawmakers would approve that. Taxpayers were still on the hook for $631 million for Soldier Field debt as of last year.\n\nThe new site would be on what are now parking lots just south of Soldier Field. The colonnades from the old structure would be saved. The proposal is believed to potentially include a hotel and improved access to and from DuSable Lake Shore Drive.\n\nThe Bears bought the former Arlington International Racecourse in Arlington Heights for $197 million last year, and announced plans for a $5 billion mixed-use development with a stadium, housing and entertainment. But the team switched focus back to Chicago this year after property tax negotiations with local school districts broke down.\n\nSeveral other communities, including Naperville and Aurora, also expressed interest in luring the Bears.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson's office declined to comment Monday, but he has recently spoken about having promising conversations with Warren and hinted at unspecified benefits that Chicago would reap from the team's continued presence downtown.\n\nDuring an unrelated news conference last Wednesday, the mayor again said \"ownership has to put some skin in the game\" when asked about the ongoing jockeying for new stadiums by the Bears as well as other Chicago sports teams such as the White Sox. He also maintained there would be no new taxes to help out the franchises.\n\n\"If we're going to build 21st century stadiums, we have to make sure that that investment is activating the entire city of Chicago, and these conversations particularly with the Bears have been quite positive,\" Johnson said. \"I appreciate the leadership of Kevin Warren. ... But no, we have not made any commitments to any new forms of revenue.\"\n\nThe last part of his statement was in response to a question about a rejected proposal from the White Sox, first reported by Crain's Chicago Business, to use part of the amusement tax to fund new stadiums for the Bears and White Sox, to which Johnson on Wednesday said, \"We didn't like the idea, it was that simple.\"\n\nGov. J.B. Pritzker has said he is not inclined to spend public money on a private business.\n\nTribune reporter Alice Yin contributed.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Professional Sports Sports {"uri": "2024-04-334448239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:05:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:05:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T21:54:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://wgntv.com/sports/bears-report/bears-unveil-plans-for-new-domed-lakefront-stadium-illinois-leaders-remain-skeptical/", "title": "Bears unveil plans for new domed lakefront stadium. Illinois leaders remain skeptical", "body": "CHICAGO -- First, the Bears showed the renderings. Then came their financial request.\n\nThe team is putting more than $2 billion on the table, plus $300 million from an NFL fund to build stadiums, but more money is needed.\n\nThe Bears want $900 million from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, 28% of the proposal.\n\n\"This is going to reinvigorate the entire city of Chicago,\" said Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson. \"It will be the crown jewel of the city of Chicago.\"\n\nThe bonding request is complicated. In addition to roughly $1 billion, the Bears want to refinance $629 million in debt from Soldier Field renovations 20 years ago using the city's hotel tax. New bonds would extend for 40 years.\n\nAdditionally, to make the stadium a reality, the Bears are proposing three phases of infrastructure and museum campus improvement. To get shovels in the ground, they're requesting $325 million from the state or federal government now, then $510 million in Phase 2, and $665 million in Phase 3.\n\n\"We need more cranes in the sky here, and that's why I want us to get beyond picking on what's wrong with this project and instead of saying what's right with it,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said.\n\n\"What I've said from the very beginning is that an investment like this requires real skin in the game from ownership, which they've done that,\" Johnson added. \"A commitment to public use - they've done that. As well as an overall committee to building a better, stronger, safer Chicago.\"\n\nSpringfield leaders say they're skeptical.\n\nGovernor JB Pritzker says he was not invited to Wednesday's Bears event.\n\n\"Look, I'm a Bears fan. I want to be clear: I want them to win and have a great place to play, but I just think that taxpayer dollars need to be protected,\" Pritzker said.\n\nThe governor notes that under the Bears' plan, they would take all of the hotel tax revenue for their stadium despite the White Sox and Red Stars seeking new homes, too.\n\n\"I'm going to say to you publicly what I said to Kevin Warren privately last week: If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail, and it would fail miserably. There's no environment for something like this today,\" said House Speaker Emanuel \"Chris\" Welch.\n\nRailing against taxpayer subsidies is former Governor Pat Quinn, who wants to take the matter to the voters.\n\n\"Give us a chance to vote at the ballot box on whether or not this proposed stadium for the Bears, this billion-dollar-boondoggle, should be allowed to happen,\" he said.\n\nThe Bears insist their plan will create 43,000 construction jobs and have an economic impact of $8 billion. But for a franchise worth $6 billion, many want the team to fund this themselves.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGN-TV"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tahman_bradley@wgntv.com", "name": "Tahman Bradley", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandon_Johnson_(athlete)", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Brandon Johnson (athlete)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_of_Chicago", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Mayor of Chicago"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soldier_Field", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Soldier Field"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Warren", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Kevin Warren"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bond_(finance)", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Bond (finance)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States", "type": "org", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Federal government of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emanuel_Chris_Welch", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Emanuel Chris Welch"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "2024-04-334438868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:49:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:49:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T21:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.sportskeeda.com/nfl/news-bears-unveil-plans-new-4-600-000-000-domed-stadium-half-funded-public-report", "title": "Bears' unveil plans for new $4,600,000,000 domed stadium half funded by public: Report", "body": "The Chicago Bears on Wednesday unveiled plans for a staggering $4.6 billion new domed lakefront stadium as their home. The arena is expected to be built south of their current Soldier Field home and will include an added green space on the Museum Campus.\n\nNotably, the franchise plans on asking the taxpayers in Chicago to pay half of the bill (approximately $2.3 billion) to help build the new stadium.\n\nAccording to reports, the cost of building the new stadium is around $3.2 billion, with an additional $1.4 billion in infrastructure.\n\nBears president Kevin Warren spoke to reporters this week and insisted that the project will be challenging.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Warren said.\n\nLast month, the NFC North team revealed it was prepared to take on more than $2 billion in funding toward the proposed publicly-owned stadium. According to reports, the proposal also calls for a $300 million loan from the NFL and $900 million in bonds from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nHowever, the project is expected to generate $8 billion in economic impact for the region. The stadium is expected to be built in three phases and could take up to five years to complete.\n\nThe Chicago Bears last won a playoff game in 2010, when they beat the Seattle Seahawks 35-24 in the divisional round. Since then, the franchise has reached the postseason only twice\n\nChicago Bears set to take Caleb Williams as top pick in 2024 NFL draft\n\nThe Chicago Bears hold the No. 1 selection in the 2024 NFL draft. {"uri": "8095561328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:14:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:14:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:14:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/chicago-wants-super-bowls-and-final-fours-the-price-nearly-5-billion/", "title": "Chicago Wants Super Bowls, Final Fours. The Price? Nearly $5B", "body": "Hosting a Super Bowl, something previously unavailable to the Bears, sits as a central piece of proposal.\n\nThe Bears, of course, are a football team, but to borrow terminology from basketball events they now hope to host, the team is now putting on a full-court press to advance their vision of a new, domed lakefront stadium.\n\nAs expected, the Bears on Wednesday unveiled a detailed vision for a new stadium just south of the existing Soldier Field, building materially from the team's initially stated intent last month to remain in the city of Chicago. Armed with an extensive deck of new renderings and a splashy hype video, team officials and Chicago mayor Brandon Johnson sought to rally support behind what would be one of the largest developments in the city's long history.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said. \"We like to do the difficult things. We like to do the things that resonate with people for generations to come. It's time for us to do something special together.\"\n\nThe proposed publicly owned stadium -- which would at last give the third-largest media market in the U.S. an opportunity to host major events such as the Super Bowl, College Football Playoff, and the Final Four -- seeks to honor the existing character of the Chicago museum campus, including a preservation of the historic Soldier Field colonnades while also building a next-generation stadium, complete with a translucent roof (above) not unlike the ones at SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles and Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas.\n\nDespite the extensive scale of the team's ambition, there remain serious questions about how the stadium will be funded. The total price tag is slightly higher than previously projected, now coming in at $3.2 billion, with at least $325 million and as much as $1.5 billion in additional infrastructure requirements. The Bears have pledged $2 billion in direct contributions, along with another $300 million in financing through the NFL. The team is asking for $900 million in public bonding, funded through the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority and backed by an existing hotel tax, while financial support for three planned phases of infrastructure improvements around the stadium is particularly undetermined.\n\n\"There are dollars that we believe exist at the state level, maybe the federal level, and potentially the city level,\" Warren said.\n\nJohnson, however, reiterated \"this project will result in no new taxes on the residents of Chicago.\" Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker was not part of the Bears' event Wednesday; he said he \"remains skeptical\" about the team's proposal, adding that \"I'm not sure this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nThe prospect of hosting a Super Bowl at the new venue was a particular part of Warren's pitch, and he cited the stadium's location within walking distance of top-tier downtown restaurants and hotels, as well as the availability of two large-scale airports.\n\n\"How many people would love to come to a Super Bowl in Chicago?\" Warren asked. \"Everyone.\"", "source": {"uri": "frontofficesports.com", {"uri": "8095737268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:14:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:14:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:14:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.enr.com/articles/58525-chicago-bears-push-plans-forward-for-46b-lakefront-stadium", "title": "Chicago Bears Push Plans Forward for $4.6B Lakefront Stadium", "body": "The Chicago Bears debuted plans April 24 to build a $4.6-billion domed stadium on property in the city's Museum Campus overlooking Lake Michigan. Insisting it no longer plans to build a stadium in the suburbs, the team said it would demolish its current nearly 100-year-old home, Soldier Field, and replace it with gardens and athletic fields.\n\nOnly Soldier Field's colonnades would be preserved under the plan that also calls for creating a 14-acre campus with panoramic views of the lake and cityscape that would include athletic fields, parks, a promenade and a plaza where food and beverages would be sold.\n\nThe 77,000-seat stadium would not have a retractable roof -- which team President Kevin Warren said would have added $2 million to the cost and would likely be used infrequently. Instead it would be covered by a translucent roof.\n\n\"You'll be indoors, but you'll have all the benefits of being outdoors. It will feel like you are outdoors,\" he said.\n\nThe team worked with Kansas City-based architectural firm Manica to create plans for the proposed stadium that would be owned by the Chicago Park District.\n\nIt also would have a north wall made of glass to highlight the city's Michigan Avenue skyline.\n\nThe team wants to fund the stadium with $2.3 billion of private funding, including a $300 million loan from the National Football League -- and $2.3 billion in public funding that would need approval by the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, a government entity created in 1987 for constructing and renovating professional sports stadiums in tIllinois.\n\n\"We are asking the [authority] to do what they were put in place to do,\" Warren said.\n\nThe team envisions the new stadium as a place where the city could host world-class events including the Super Bowl, Olympics or college level basketball finals. It would also welcome school teams to play and host events such as concerts or graduation ceremonies.\n\nKaren Murphy, executive vice president of stadium development for the Bears, said the overall project would be constructed in phases.\n\nThe first phase would include $325 million for roadway and utility improvements, which she said are crucial to a new stadium.\n\n\"We need the $325 million [for infrastructure improvements] to open the stadium,\" said Murphy, explaining that the team would seek city, state and federal funds to pay for these improvements.\n\nThe second phase of the campus would require $510 million for parking, new parks and playing fields. The third phase would be $665 million for additional transportation improvements, retail and public attractions.\n\nEvoking the legacy of Daniel Burnham who advocated in the early 20th century to keep the lakefront open to the public, Warren said the plan is in keeping with a city ordinance intended to protect that area from development.\n\n\"This will create 20% more open space for the city of Chicago,\" he said.\n\nThe Friends of the Parks released a statement opposing the new stadium.\n\n\"Once again, Chicago taxpayers are being told what is good for them,\" the statement reads. \"We are told that a new domed stadium on protected lakefront land will make Chicago a great city. We are already a great city -- in large part due to our protected lakefront. As is so often the case in Chicago, the powerful and wealthy are demanding that our entire city stop and fast-track their plans to expand operations on the people's lakefront.\"\n\nWarren said the team is abandoning its plan to build a stadium on 325 acres it previously purchased in northwest suburban Arlington Heights.\n\n\"We are clear that our focus is on the city of Chicago and the museum campus,\" he said, estimating that the project would have an $8 billion economic impact on the region.", "source": {"uri": "enr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Engineering News-Record (ENR) magazine"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soldier_Field", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Soldier Field"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8095706589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:37:17", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:37:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:36:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/why-do-bears-want-to-build-fixed-roof-dome-president-shares-new-details-explaining-decision/3419716/", "title": "Why do Bears want to build fixed-roof dome? President shares new details explaining decision", "body": "Bears president/CEO Kevin Warren said the team considered a retractable roof and explained why they decided against it\n\nFor as long as the Bears have talked about new stadium plans, they've talked about their future stadium having a fixed roof. From former president Ted Phillips to current president Kevin Warren, from Arlington Heights to Chicago, building a domed stadium has been a constant. On Wednesday, Warren shared some more details on why the team will opt for a sealed dome rather than a retractable roof.\n\n\"That's another couple $100 million, and when we talked to organizations who had retractable roofs they said they used it maybe three or four times a year,\" Warren said. \"We tried to be fiscally responsible by building the stadium.\"\n\nWarren led the charge for the Vikings' U.S. Bank stadium project, which also has a fixed roof and pointed to that stadium, along with the Raiders' Allegiant Stadium and the Rams' SoFi Stadium as examples. Those stadiums are known for big, translucent windows to allow natural light to filter into the stadium. Warren said the proposed Bears stadium in Chicago would have the same, and offer views of the surrounding city.\n\n\"You'll feel like you're outdoors, that you may have to wear sunglasses,\" Warren said.\n\nThe renderings the Bears released are impressive looking, but Illinois lawmakers splashed water on the idea that they will come to pass for certain. Before the presentation began, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker said he was skeptical of the proposal to build a new publicly-owned stadium in the city.\n\n\"I wonder if it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker said. \"It's very important to me that, with all the state needs to accomplish, that we think about what the priorities are for the state... there are a lot of priorities the state has and I'm not sure that this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nAfter the presentation, Illinois Senate President Dan Harmon added his voice to the conversation.\n\n\"At first glance, more than $2 billion in private funding is better than zero and a more credible opening offer,\" Harmon said in a statement. \"But there's an obvious, substantial gap remaining, and I echo the governor's skepticism.\"\n\nPer the Bears presentation, they project their full stadium project will cost $4.7 billion. The team said it would contribute just over $2 billion, ask for $300 million from the NFL, and look to the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority for $900 million. That leaves a gap of about $1.5 billion, and the team would look for public money to make up the difference. Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson was emphatic in saying there would be no new taxes for Chicago residents. That seemingly leaves the team to look for state or federal dollars.\n\nThe Bears bought 326 acres of land in Arlington Heights last year, and previously announced plans to build a new stadium there. But contentious negotiations about property taxes in the suburbs have become an obstacle for that plan. Earlier this year the team said it was switching its focus away from Arlington Heights back to the city.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Warren", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kevin Warren"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retractable_roof", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Retractable roof"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren,_Ohio", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Warren, Ohio"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Warren, Ohio"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SoFi_Stadium", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "SoFi Stadium"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Illinois"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegiant_Stadium", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Allegiant Stadium"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "8095651440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:38:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:38:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T21:38:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/taxpayers-infrastructure-planned-new-bears-stadium/", "title": "Taxpayers could be on the hook for infrastructure around planned new Bears stadium, expert says", "body": "CHICAGO (CBS) -- The Chicago Bears on Wednesday unveiled their multibillion-dollar plan for a new domed stadium on the lakefront, just south of their current home of Soldier Field -- but it comes with a huge bill, and it remained unclear Wednesday how taxpayers might be on the hook for the cost of the surrounding infrastructure.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson denied that the Bears' shiny new dome could end up costing taxpayers a pretty penny.\n\n\"What it does not call for are raising taxes, or implementing new taxes on residents of the city of Chicago,\" the mayor said.\n\nHe made this claim repeatedly.\n\n\"One more time, to make sure that everybody that -- this project will result in no new taxes on the residents of Chicago,\" Johnson later added.\n\nHowever, the project is not just the stadium itself. It will include the surrounding park area, and the infrastructure around the Museum Campus nearby.\n\nThe Bears are planning to contribute $2.3 billion, including a $300 million loan from the NFL, to the $3.2 billion cost of the stadium, and will seek $900 million in public funding through 40-year bonds issued by the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which helped fund the 2002 renovation of Soldier Field, as well as the construction and renovations of Guaranteed Rate Field, the home of the White Sox.\n\nThe $900 million in public funding for the stadium would come from an existing 2% hotel tax that already goes to the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nThe Bears also would ask to refinance existing debt from the prior work at Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field\n\nThat funding plan would require approval from the Illinois General Assembly.\n\nMeanwhile, the surrounding infrastructure is expected to cost $1.5 billion -- for a grand total of $4.7 billion for the plan.\n\n\"The infrastructure component of this, which is the place that is most immediately, directly and likely to be the taxpayer burden; to be the government financing burden,\" said Joe Ferguson, president of the Civic Federation.\n\nFerguson agreed that the infrastructure bill amounts to a hidden cost to the Chicago taxpayer.\n\nThe Bears and the City of Chicago suggested they would ask the federal government to front at least some of the remaining bill.\n\n\"There's substantial infrastructure funding that comes from the federal government gets remitted to the state, and becomes available for projects around the state,\" Chicago Chief Financial Officer Jill Jaworski said Wednesday. \"We will be working with the state to pursue those funds for the road work that's going to be needed.\"\n\nWarren said he's hoping to get approval of the financing plan from the Illinois General Assembly this spring, and to begin construction in the summer of 2025.\n\nBut experts worry about how the money might flow, depending on who sits in the Oval Office.\n\n\"Let's put a fine point on it,\" said Ferguson. \"If Donald Trump is president, the federal spigot gets turned off -- period.\"\n\nThere is also doubt over possible taxpayer funding for the infrastructure money in Springfield. Gov. JB Pritzker has said he's willing to consider the Bears' plans, but has voiced reluctance to provide public funding for the project.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal, and I wonder whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker said Wednesday morning at an unrelated event before the Bears' formal announcement. \"It's very important to me that, with all that the state needs to accomplish, that we think about what the priorities are of the state.\"\n\nPritzker also noted that public financing for stadium deals has become more unpopular in recent years, pointing to Missouri voters earlier this month rejecting a proposed sales tax hike to help fund renovations to Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, just months after the Chiefs won their third Super Bowl in five years.\n\n\"I think this is, you know, a recognition that these are private businesses; that the owners of these private businesses need to put a lot more forward in order to ... have their dreams fulfilled, and not just rely upon the taxpayers of Illinois to make that happen for them,\" he said. \"Having said that, I think all of us want success for the state. We want more commerce. We want more jobs. We want our teams to be successful. So, you know, we share all of that in common, but we've got to use our dollars wisely.\"\n\nBears president Kevin Warren cautioned that the time to get the stadium deal done is now. He believes the longer Chicago and Springfield wait, the more the cost will go up.\n\nWarren said he looks forward to meeting with lawmakers in Springfield to iron out the details.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095669119", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T21:56:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.wgem.com/2024/04/24/bears-unveil-new-stadium-plan-gov-pritzker-legislative-leaders-skeptical-using-taxpayer-dollars/", "title": "Bears unveil new stadium plan; Gov. Pritzker, legislative leaders 'skeptical' of using taxpayer dollars", "body": "CHICAGO (WGEM) - The Chicago Bears are asking taxpayers for about $2.4 billion to build a new stadium project next to their current stadium, Soldier Field, along Lake Michigan in downtown Chicago.\n\nThe team unveiled its proposal Wednesday at an event at Soldier Field with Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson.\n\nThe team and the NFL plans to contribute about $2.3 billion towards the development.\n\nThe proposal calls for the state using the existing Illinois Sports Facilities Authority (ISFA) to contribute $900 million to the $3.225 billion stadium. The project would also call for an additional $1.5 billion to improve infrastructure around the stadium using taxpayer dollars.\n\nOriginally created when the Chicago White Sox built was is now Guaranteed Rate Field, the ISFA was also used to renovate that stadium and Soldier Field. It still owes more than $400 million on the Soldier Field renovation, which was finished in 2003. It's funded through an existing 2% hotel tax. The Bears' proposal also calls for the ISFA to refinance its existing debt.\n\nThe Bears estimate the project would create 43,000 construction jobs and generate an annual economic impact of $456 million once the project is completed.\n\nWhen asked about the proposal Wednesday, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker and legislative leaders were skeptical of the proposal.\n\n\"I believe strongly that this is not a high priority for legislators and certainly for me when I compare it to all the other things,\" Pritzker, a Democrat, said.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue for a vote on the board right now it would fail and it would fail miserably. There's no environment for something like this today. Now, in Springfield, environments change. Will that environment change within the next 30 days? I think that's highly unlikely,\" said Illinois House Speaker Emmanuel \"Chris\" Welch, D-Hillside.\n\nThe 2024 legislative session is scheduled to end May 24.\n\nWhen asked about potentially waiting until the fall veto session for lawmakers to pass stadium funding legislation, Bears President and CEO Kevin Warren said he would prefer to get the legislation done sooner.\n\nIllinois Senate President Don Harmon, D-Oak Park, also released a statement Wednesday about the stadium proposal:\n\n\"At first glance, more than $2 billion in private funding is better than zero and a more credible opening offer. But there's an obvious, substantial gap remaining, and I echo the governor's skepticism.\"\n\nThe Bears funding request comes as the White Sox are asking the state for $1 billion to build a new stadium in Chicago. {"uri": "8095287844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:34:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:34:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:33:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/bears-to-announce-plans-for-new-digs/article_e0e444ed-ea96-550d-b680-482bdd52fcd3.html", "title": "Bears to announce plans for new digs", "body": "CHICAGO TRIBUNE\n\nCHICAGO BEARS\n\nThe Chicago Bears have set noon Wednesday to announce plans for a new domed stadium on the lakefront.\n\nTeam officials will make the announcement at Soldier Field, which would be demolished under the proposal.\n\nIn what will be a busy week for the team, the announcement will come one day before the Bears are scheduled to make the No. 1 pick in the NFL Draft.\n\nThe team said it plans to present a \"state-of-the-art, publicly owned enclosed stadium, along with additional green and open space with access to the lakefront for families and fans, on the Museum Campus.\"\n\nThe team has pledged to spend $2 billion in private money for the project. The cost of the stadium is estimated at $2.5 billion to $3 billion, plus $1 billion for associated roads and other infrastructure.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection Flick Fact: The sad legacy of one former and ultimately famous B-N resident?\n\n\"If we're going to build 21st century stadiums, we have to make sure that that investment is activating the entire city of Chicago.\"\n\nBrandon Johnson, Chicago Mayor\n\nThe crucial question is how any taxpayer cost would be funded, and whether city and state lawmakers would approve that. Taxpayers were still on the hook for $631 million for Soldier Field debt as of last year.\n\nThe new site would be on what are now parking lots just south of Soldier Field. The colonnades from the old structure would be saved. The proposal is believed to potentially include a hotel and improved access to and from DuSable Lake Shore Drive.\n\nThe Bears bought the former Arlington International Racecourse in Arlington Heights for $197 million last year, and announced plans for a $5 billion mixed-use development with a stadium, housing and entertainment. But the team switched focus back to Chicago this year after property tax negotiations with local school districts broke down.\n\nSeveral other communities, including Naperville and Aurora, also expressed interest in luring the Bears.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson's office declined to comment Monday, but he has recently spoken about having promising conversations with Warren and hinted at unspecified benefits that Chicago would reap from the team's continued presence downtown.\n\nDuring an unrelated news conference last Wednesday, the mayor again said \"ownership has to put some skin in the game\" when asked about the ongoing jockeying for new stadiums by the Bears as well as other Chicago sports teams such as the White Sox. He also maintained there would be no new taxes to help out the franchises.\n\n\"If we're going to build 21st century stadiums, we have to make sure that that investment is activating the entire city of Chicago, and these conversations particularly with the Bears have been quite positive,\" Johnson said. \"I appreciate the leadership of Kevin Warren. ... But no, we have not made any commitments to any new forms of revenue.\"\n\nThe last part of his statement was in response to a question about a rejected proposal from the White Sox, first reported by Crain's Chicago Business, to use part of the amusement tax to fund new stadiums for the Bears and White Sox, to which Johnson on Wednesday said, \"We didn't like the idea, it was that simple.\"\n\nGov. J.B. Pritzker has said he is not inclined to spend public money on a private business.\n\nTribune reporter Alice Yin contributed.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Sports Finance The Economy {"uri": "8095593052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "20:43:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T20:43:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:42:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "http://blockclubchicago.org/2024/04/24/heres-what-the-bears-3-2-billion-lakefront-stadium-could-look-like/", "title": "Here's What The Bears $3.2 Billion Lakefront Stadium Could Look Like", "body": "DOWNTOWN -- The Chicago Bears unveiled the first renderings for a $3.2 billion domed lakefront stadium as team leaders made their pitch to the city Wednesday.\n\nPlans call for a \"publicly owned\" domed stadium with expanded recreation areas for fans and families to enjoy. It would also include infrastructure improvements to the surrounding green space, added playfields, public restrooms and food and beverage offerings.\n\nSoldier Field would be demolished and replaced with sports fields and gardens, team leaders said. The stadium's historic colonnades would be preserved.\n\nTotal cost of the project is projected to be $4.6 billion -- $3.2 billion to build the stadium, along with $1.4 billion in proposed infrastructure upgrades. The Bears would foot half the bill and taxpayers would cover the rest, officials said.\n\nThe team estimates that the new stadium will bring in $8 billion in regional economic impact, along with 43,000 construction jobs and 4,200 new jobs to the metro area. The Bears would use it to host Super Bowls, NCAA championships, concerts and more.\n\n\"Contributing more than $2 billion in private dollars into this new publicly-owned stadium will unlock tremendous economic development opportunities, add jobs for the city and the region, and create a tremendous home field advantage for the Chicago Bears,\" Bears President and CEO Kevin Warren said in a statement.\n\nThe ability to host so many major events also \"means billions of tourism dollars that Chicago currently cannot capture -- helping our city regain its reputation for hosting global events,\" Warren said.\n\nThe team said it would seek out local minority-, women- and veteran-owned construction businesses for the project.\n\nThe plan has the support of Mayor Brandon Johnson, who touted it as way to bring about \"economic growth and community enrichment.\"\n\n\"The proposed stadium, accompanied by expanded open spaces and recreational facilities, exemplifies my administration's commitment to enhancing the quality of life for all Chicagoans. I commend the team for their dedication to serving the greater good with private investment, and I look forward to the positive impact it will have on our beloved city,\" Johnson said in a "place", "label": {"eng": "Warren, Ohio"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Greyhound Racing/Tracks", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bcc-newspack.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/2024/04/BearsDomed2.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9503122", "eventUri": "eng-9503122", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Downtown Los Angeles"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2313725490196079, "wgt": 166, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8097268390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "18:35:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T18:35:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T18:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/breaking-down-the-politics-at-play-in-bears-stadium-plan/article_37e999b6-02c8-11ef-9c72-430b7b0bed13.html", "title": "Moore: Breaking down the politics at play in Bears' stadium plan", "body": "SPRINGFIELD -- As Chicago Bears officials laid out their $4.7 billion plan for a new domed stadium on the city's lakefront, Mayor Brandon Johnson and others cheered as if the NFL's founding franchise had just scored a touchdown.\n\nBut the team seems to be throwing a \"Hail Mary\" pass in Springfield, where state lawmakers and Gov. J.B. Pritzker appear unlikely to do the blocking and tackling necessary to muscle through legislation that would unlock the $900 million in public funding the team says is needed for the project.\n\nThe long-awaited plan, unveiled at a Wednesday press conference at Soldier Field, calls for a $3.2 billion stadium along with at least $325 million but perhaps as much as $1.5 billion for infrastructure upgrades.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs NCHS placed on 'hold' Wednesday morning; students and staff safe Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site District 87 teachers get first look at newly purchased Oakland Avenue Building Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington Coroner: Pekin woman dead after forklift accident in Goodfield Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection Illinois State basketball adds former Northern Iowa guard\n\nThe Bears have pledged about $2.3 billion toward stadium construction while asking the state, through the Illinois State Facilities Authority, to issue $900 million in taxpayer-backed bonds to cover the rest. The city and state would also be on the hook for the infrastructure bill.\n\nISFA-issued bonds, which were used to build Guaranteed Rate Field and renovate Soldier Field, are backed by an existing 2% city hotel tax.\n\nBonds for those earlier projects are set to expire in 2033. The Bears have proposed issuing new bonds to be paid back over a 40-year period. This would require the approval of state lawmakers.\n\n\"This project will result in no new taxes on the residents of Chicago,\" Johnson said in backing public funding, proclaiming that the new stadium had the potential to be \"the crown jewel of the city of Chicago.\"\n\nBears President Kevin Warren, though conceding that \"this is not an easy project,\" said that by working together, the team, city and state can \"create win-win-win situations.\"\n\nBut 15 miles away from the glitzy rollout event, Pritzker and legislative leaders said they remained unconvinced that the Bears' proposal is a \"win\" for taxpayers.\n\n\"I'm highly skeptical of the proposal that's been made and I believe strongly that this is not a high priority for legislators and certainly not for me,\" Pritzker told reporters at an unrelated press conference in Maywood to promote his health insurance reform legislation.\n\nPritzker then observed that voters in Kansas City just rejected a referendum that would have authorized public funding for a new Royals ballpark and renovations to Arrowhead Stadium, home of the Super Bowl Champion Chiefs.\n\n\"I don't really think that the people of Chicago or across Illinois feel any different than that,\" Pritzker said, adding that he had not been invited to the Bears' announcement.\n\nHouse Speaker Chris Welch, D-Hillside, at the same event, said that if he \"were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably.\" Senate President Don Harmon, D-Oak Park, said in a statement that he echoed Pritzker's skepticism.\n\nWarren, however, said \"the time is now\" to get a stadium deal done, insisting that the team will push for a package before lawmakers adjourn their spring session at the end of May and not punt to the fall veto session. He said waiting could cost valuable time, both delaying the stadium's opening date and increasing the overall project cost.\n\nCould the Bears come out of the state Capitol winners in a few weeks? Sure.\n\nEven Welch, who said it is \"highly unlikely\" that the Bears can get the deal they're looking for in this political climate, acknowledged that \"in Springfield, environments change.\"\n\nBut if I were the Bears, I would consider drawing up a new game plan. The same with the White Sox. And the Chicago Red Stars. And any other Illinois team looking for a public subsidy for a new stadium.\n\nAs I wrote last month regarding the White Sox's quest for a new ballpark, the amount of doubt and distaste for public funding in the Capitol should not be underestimated and cannot be overstated.\n\nThat's true in both the House and Senate. But look no further than Pritzker. Illinois' billionaire governor has remained consistent in his general opposition to public subsidies for facilities used by privately owned teams and in his skepticism of the projects that have specifically been floated.\n\nOf course, politicians can changed their minds.\n\nLook at Johnson, a former Chicago Teachers Union organizer elected with heavy support from the progressive grassroots. He opposed subsidies as a candidate last year but flipped to the point of being part of the Bears' rollout announcement on Wednesday.\n\nBut I'm not so sure about Pritzker in this instance. In the 2 1/2 years since he started to be asked about this topic, there's been little deviation off his general position despite shifting plans from the Bears and added wrenches like the Sox's trial balloon.\n\nFor instance, when asked about the possibility of helping to finance a stadium project following the Bears' September 2021 announcement of a purchase agreement for the 326-acre Arlington Park property, Pritzker said \"that's not something that we're looking at.\"\n\nHe was asked again in a gubernatorial debate in October 2022 -- his answer even more to the point: \"Look, I'm a Bears fan. I support the Chicago Bears. But, I do not think that the state should be funding the private development of a stadium anywhere in the state.\"\n\nIn April 2023, Pritzker told reporters in response to a legislative proposal that would lock in the Bears' property tax rates for the now-mothballed Arlington Park development \"that the state really shouldn't be in the business of providing handouts to private industry and that's what the Bears are.\"\n\nWhen the Sox entered the fray earlier this year with a proposal for a publicly-financed ballpark in the city's South Loop neighborhood, Pritzker said that he started out \"really reluctant\" and would be against it \"unless a case is made that the investment yields a long-term return for the taxpayers,\" something he said had not yet been displayed.\n\nIn March, Pritzker said that the Bears' commitment of $2 billion private money towards the project was \"a good first step\" but alone not enough to warrant state involvement in the project.\n\n\"I want to say one more time: We're prioritizing the use of dollars here for people who need it,\" Pritzker said. \"Wealthy owners of sports teams, I respect that they run private businesses and they want them to be profitable and they want constantly to provide better facilities for their customers. But I don't think that should be the highest priority for the state of Illinois.\"\n\nHe may say it a little differently each time, but the message has essentially been the same. In this context, it's hard to see Pritzker moving off such a long-held position in the course of just a few weeks.\n\nNow, there are things the Bears can do to drum up support in the legislature and perhaps turn up pressure on Pritzker and others.\n\nThe smart play is probably to deploy organized labor to help sell the plan. The unions collectively still have enough clout to make a difference under the Capitol dome. They will be incentivized by the promise of thousands of stadium construction jobs to help the Bears and perhaps the Sox.\n\nBut again, if past is prologue, that will not deter Pritzker from his stance.\n\nKevin Warren and the Bears have four weeks to draw up a legislative play in Springfield. But they may need to call an audible.\n\nHistory photos: Chicago's Soldier Field through the years Soldier Field - 2003 Soldier Field - 1971 Soldier Field - 1931 Soldier Field - 1959 Soldier Field - 1987 Soldier Field - 1926 Soldier Field - 1933 Soldier Field - 1928 Soldier Field - 1939 Soldier Field - 1962 Soldier Field - 1946 Soldier Field - 1978 Soldier Field - 1959 Soldier Field - 1959 Soldier Field - 1943 Soldier Field - 1936 Soldier Field - 1932 Soldier Field - 1961 Soldier Field - 1974 Soldier Field - 1948 Soldier Field - 1927 Soldier Field - 1959 Soldier Field - 1927 Soldier Field - 1973 Soldier Field - 2003\n\nContact Brenden Moore at brenden.moore@lee.net. Follow him on Twitter: @brendenmoore13\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Politics Finance The Economy Sports American Football Trade Institutions Law Construction Industry Legislation Computer Science Job Market Architecture Games And Toys Baseball Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {"uri": "8093981580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "01:13:31", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T01:13:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T01:13:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/football/s-3217407", "title": "Taxpayers would pick up half the tab for Bears' lakefront stadium, sources say", "body": "CHICAGO -- The Chicago Bears are set to announce a $4.6 billion plan for a new enclosed stadium and lakefront area, half of which would come from taxpayers, sources said, but the team will have to overcome serious skepticism from several directions.\n\nThe stadium itself would cost $3.2 billion to build, with another $1.4 billion in proposed infrastructure improvements, according to sources familiar with the plan who spoke to the Chicago Tribune on the condition of anonymity.\n\nThe sources said the Bears plan to pledge $2.3 billion, which include some financing through the NFL. But the Bears' plan includes an additional $2.3 billion in public financing, along with refinancing outstanding debt for prior publicly financed stadium projects for the Bears and White Sox, according to the sources.\n\nTaxpayers would be on the hook for the proposed infrastructure improvements along with about $1 billion in new borrowing to finance the new stadium south of Soldier Field, the sources said.\n\nTo make the plan a reality, the Bears want the Illinois General Assembly to approve $1.5 billion in new bonding for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which carries the debt for prior projects at Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, sources said.\n\nAbout one-third of the new borrowing would be used to roll over existing stadium debt, and the plan calls for the new borrowing to be paid off over 40 years, which also would require legislative approval.\n\nSources said the Bears' plan calls for the debt to be repaid without raising the 2% hotel tax that currently goes to ISFA.\n\nThe details are expected to be revealed at a much-anticipated news conference at noon Wednesday where officials will lay out plans for the domed stadium with increased open space.\n\nThe 2% hotel tax has fallen far short of paying off the existing debt. As a result, taxpayers still owe $629 million for past renovations of Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, whose occupants, the White Sox, also are seeking a new stadium in the South Loop. To finance a new Bears stadium using the hotel tax, the state would have to increase the borrowing limit for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nThat could prove to be a tough sell in Springfield, however, where legislative leaders so far have given the Bears, and the Sox, a cool reception.\n\n...continued", "source": {"uri": "arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArcaMax"}, {"uri": "8094049274", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "02:35:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T02:35:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T02:35:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10118277-report-bears-new-stadium-plan-projected-to-cost-46b-half-from-public-financing", "title": "Report: Bears New Stadium Plan Projected to Cost $4.6B; Half from Public Financing", "body": "The Chicago Bears haven't won a playoff game in 13 years, but they reportedly plan on asking residents of their city to foot a $2.3 billion bill to help build a new stadium south of their current Soldier Field home.\n\nAccording to a Tuesday report from the Chicago Tribune, the NFC North team is on the verge of announcing a new $4.6 billion plan for an enclosed stadium along the Chicago lakefront. The plan will call for $3.2 billion to build the stadium and an additional $1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements.\n\nYet the Bears intend to cover just $2.3 billion of that cost with some financing through the NFL. J.B. Pritzker", "body": "Brandon Johnson responds to stadium skepticism from Friends of the Parks, Gov. J.B. Pritzker originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nProminent Chicago preservation group Friends of the Parks responded Wednesday to the highly anticipated reveal of the Bears' newest stadium proposal in Chicago, which includes tearing down much of the current Soldier Field in order to build a domed facility and more.\n\nFriends of the Parks, which successfully sued to prevent George Lucas from building a museum along the lakefront, has previously voiced opposition to the construction of any new stadium project on the Museum Campus, where the Bears are proposing their new stadium site.\n\n\"The 'Chicago Way' was on full display at the Chicago Bears news conference today. Once again, Chicago taxpayers are being told what is good for them. We are told that a new domed stadium on protected lakefront land will make Chicago a great city,\" the group said in response to the announcement. \"We are already a great city -- in large part due to our protected lakefront. As is so often the case in Chicago, the powerful and wealthy are demanding that our entire city stop and fast-track their plans to expand operations on the people's lakefront.\"\n\nMORE: Friends of the Parks responds to Bears' new stadium proposal\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson joined NBC Sports Chicago's \"Football Night in Chicago\" to respond to the criticism from Friends of the Parks and their concerns for the lakefront ordinance, which prohibits privately invested structures built east of Lakeshore Drive.\n\n\"Well, you know, again, the lakefront protected ordinance, you know, which I'm fully in support of,\" Johnson said. \"I'm confident that we are not in opposition to that ordinance. Again, we're talking about 20% more open [green] space. The amount of investments that are going into creating 14 more acres of space for our children and our young\n\npeople in the city of Chicago to benefit from that.\n\n\"That's been the vision for the lakefront for some time. You know, look, I know that there has been a regular practice in the city of Chicago where things have just been rammed down people's throats. This is a proposal. What we're saying is we have an opportunity to not just keep the Bears in the city of Chicago, but 24,000 jobs, construction jobs just for the people of Chicago. 46,000 construction jobs for the region. 2.5 billion, 3.5 billion in Chicago region of labor income, the type of income that's needed to afford to live in the city of Chicago. That's what this proposal provides.\n\n\"And so I'm looking forward to the continued conversation. And again, this notion that we were going to lose the Bears to another space, we didn't do that. This notion that we could not provide a development with real collaboration for public benefit. We've done that. The fact that we have created public use. We've done that. The fact that we are creating opportunities for our young people, our students and a Catholic League. Like could you imagine, you know, these, high-stakes tournaments where young people get a chance to participate downtown with the lakeshore as the backdrop, on a Saturday night or a Sunday night?\n\n\"Graduations can be held there. There are so many different opportunities that we have at this moment. And make no mistake about it, my job and my responsibility is to make sure that the people of Chicago benefit from any investment. And that's what this proposal does.\"\n\nJohnson and the Bears spoke at Soldier Field Wednesday about their plan for a new stadium. Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, according to him, was not invited to the press conference to speak.\n\nHow does Johnson respond to the lack of alignment between the city of Chicago and the state of Illinois?\n\n\"Well, I run the city of Chicago,\" Johnson said. \"I mean, that's my responsibility to people in Chicago voted for me to run the city. And what the city has made very clear is that the public use and the public benefits to transform the lakefront. That has always been my goal. It's not about just keeping the bears in the city of Chicago, which we have a commitment from the Bears to remain in Chicago, but it's also about the transformation that exists there.\n\n\"Now, as far as the next steps, of course, to engage the speaker of the House, the Senate president to engage the governor, to engage the people of Chicago as a whole. That is also part of the process. But we needed to make sure that the Bears organization in my administration were on the same page. And when it comes to investing in this moment, creating hundreds of thousands of jobs, we're talking about $3.5 billion of income in four workers.\n\n\"That's transformational. We're also talking about the long-term sustainability of this opportunity to have 20% more open green space, 14 acres of new fields for our young people to be able to participate in. This is a win-win-win for the city of Chicago. The team said it would contribute just over $2 billion, ask for $300 million from the NFL, and look to the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority for $900 million. That leaves a gap of about $1.5 billion, and the team would look for public money to make up the difference.\n\nMeanwhile Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson was emphatic in saying there would be no new taxes for Chicago residents.\n\nAs Harmon alluded to, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker said he remains \"skeptical\" about the Bears proposal to build a new publicly-owned stadium in Chicago, before the presentation began.\n\n\"I wonder if it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" Pritzker said. \"It's very important to me that, with all the state needs to accomplish, that we think about what the priorities are for the state... there are a lot of priorities the state has and I'm not sure that this is among the highest priorities for taxpayers.\"\n\nThe Bears bought 326 acres of land in Arlington Heights last year, and previously announced plans to build a new stadium there. But contentious negotiations about property taxes in the suburbs have become an obstacle for that plan. Of course, they aren't planning to pay for it themselves.\n\nThe team is planning to reveal plans for a $4.6 billion project to build a new enclosed stadium on the Lake Michigan lakefront area, according to the Chicago Tribune, with the team planning to pledge $2.3 billion to make it happen. That would leave Illinois taxpayers on the hook for $2.3 billion.\n\nFor perspective, that works out to $183 per Illinois resident.\n\nThe stadium itself will reportedly cost $3.2 billion to build, with another $1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements (think public transportation, parking garages, parks). Taxpayers would technically cover the infrastructure improvements and $1 billion in newly borrowed money, which would involve new bonds for the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority (ISFA).\n\nA $4.6 billion stadium (or a $3.2 billion stadium) would be the second-most expensive stadium in sports history, behind only SoFi Stadium, the home of the Los Angeles Rams and Los Angeles Chargers. That project was funded entirely by Rams owner Stan Kroenke.\n\nThese plans come after the Bears already spent $197 million to buy the Arlington International Racecourse property in Arlington Heights, Ill. They are now apparently set to abandon those plans, with the team reportedly unable to reach an agreement over property taxes with local schools in Arlington Heights.\n\nThe Bears' lease at Soldier Field, which is nearing its 100th birthday, runs through 2033.\n\nThe Bears are pursuing their public funding in parallel to the Chicago White Sox, which have already unveiled plans for a stadium just outside Chicago's South Loop area.\n\nThe price tag was initially reported as $1 billion, but a subsequent interview by team owner Jerry Reinsdorf revealed the price tag would be more around $2 billion. He heavily hinted that Illinois declining to cover the money would endanger the team's future in Chicago.\n\nIt remains to be seen if the Bears will employ similar scare tactics, and if anyone would believe them. The teams have recently discussed a financial partnership.\n\nThe Bears and White Sox already had some financial ties, as they both received their most recent major rounds of funding for stadiums via the ISFA.\n\nA 2% hotel tax has been used to pay bonds that covered renovations for Soldier Field and Guaranteed Rate Field, but the debts have outpaced that income. Per the Tribune, taxpayers still owe $629 million on renovations for stadiums that both teams are now trying to abandon while asking Illinois to pay billions to help them to do so.\n\nSome of the proposed borrowing would reportedly be used to roll over that debt, with a plan to pay it off over the course of 40 years.\n\nOne sports economist the Tribune spoke to, J.C.
