{"uri": "2024-04-332859366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "16:16:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T16:16:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T15:28:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.journal-topics.com/articles/bears-stadium-plans-include-soldier-field-demo-new-lacrosse-softball-sites-colonnade-preservation/", "title": "Bears Stadium Plans Include Soldier Field Demo, New Lacrosse, Softball Sites, Colonnade Preservation", "body": "Tomorrow's (Wednesday) unveiling by the Chicago Bears of a proposed new domed stadium along the Lake Michigan shoreline south of Soldier Field will elevate Chicago to a new level where supporters envision Super Bowls and possibly the selling of naming rights of the arena, all of which will generate billions of dollars for the regional economy.\n\nCertain state and Chicago leaders recently got a sneak preview of the plans that the Bears will roll out to the public Wednesday at a press conference at Soldier Field. The Bears have been playing their home games there since 1970.\n\nThe plan, which would require a long list of government approvals such as using Chicago hotel tax revenue to pay for part of the development, most likely will include the demolition of Soldier Field. The historic colonnades on the east and west sides of the stadium would be preserved somehow and somewhere. They were part of the original Neo-classical design. They pay homage to the ancient Roman Colosseum. The stadium as a whole is an expression of reverence for the men and women who have served in the U.S. military.\n\nThe stadium opened on Oct. 9, 1924, to serve as a space where a variety of events such as athletic competitions, exhibitions and other gatherings could be held. It was not intended to become a stadium for football. That came a few years later.\n\nThe announcement Wednesday will be the start of one of the biggest weeks in the 105-year history of the Bears professional football team.\n\nThe Bears, due to its poor records of the last few years, have the No. 1 pick in the draft that will be held from this Thursday to Saturday in Detroit. They plan to choose 22-year-old quarterback Caleb Sequan Williams who played his college football at the University of Oklahoma and the University of Southern California. Williams won the Heisman Trophy and several other awards with USC in 2022 after throwing for over 4,500 yards with 52 total touchdowns. Construction of a new stadium along the lakefront would take several years to complete. Added to the mix is the Chicago White Sox proposal for a new stadium in the same area as well.\n\nIn the end, the state of Illinois would own one or both of the new arenas. The Chicago Park District would retain ownership of Soldier Field. Once it's demolished, the land would become lacrosse, softball and other fields for public enjoyment. The roof of the arena would not be retractable due to Chicago's precarious weather throughout the year. While the Bears football season generally runs from August to the end of the year, the new stadium would host events like concerts, professional soccer games, shows, and other gatherings year-round.", There's a possibility there. But one of the things I promised myself and promised the McCaskeys is that I would come in and take a fresh look at what's the right thing to do.\n\n* Friends of the Parks and the Bears sat down in March. Crain's...\n\nAt the meeting, Friends of the Parks continued to advocate for the Bears to instead build a stadium at the former Michael Reese hospital site, but team executives explained their concerns, including that the Reese site is too narrow and could potentially involve pushing residents out of their homes to make way for the stadium. [...]\n\nAfter the meeting, both parties issued statements acknowledging the meeting but did not provide specifics on what was discussed.\n\n\"The Chicago Bears met with Friends of the Parks to discuss our mutual dedication to Chicago and our deep love for our city's parks and lakefront area. We look forward to continuing to work together to strengthen our city,\" a Bears spokesman said in a statement.\n\n\"Friends of the Parks had the opportunity to sit down with the Chicago Bears and hear their vision for a new stadium. They also had an opportunity to hear our values. We look forward to future meetings and conversations with a broader group of stakeholders,\" Friends of the Parks said through a spokesperson.\n\n* Yesterday, Friends of the Parks responded to the Chicago Bears news conference...\n\nThe \"Chicago Way\" was on full display at the Chicago Bears news conference today. Once again, Chicago taxpayers are being told what is good for them. We are told that a new domed stadium on protected lakefront land will make Chicago a great city. We are already a great city -- in large part due to our protected lakefront. As is so often the case in Chicago,the powerful and wealthy are demanding that our entire city stop and fast track their plans to expand operations on the people's lakefront.\n\nMeanwhile, the communities we work with who are addressing immigrant issues, homelessness, school closures, affordable housing, public safety, equitable transportation, and lack of jobs are fighting for parity-including at our Chicago Park District parks.\n\nWe are all being asked to trust the process and accept that it will, in fact, be Bear-a-dice. Yet, Chicago has a long history of, closed-door planning and rushed decision-making that does not end well for taxpayers. Just look at The Lincoln Yards, The 78, a Chicago casino, and the infamous parking meter deal. Each of these was going to make Chicago into a \"world class\" city and be a \"win-win-win\" for residents.\n\nThe questions everyone needs to ask of the Bears organization and our elected officials are:\n\nThis is a time for some thoughtful, deliberate and civic engagement. A civil, community-driven conversation should be at the forefront of any action the city of Chicago takes regarding the lakefront.\n\nWe did not hear anything at the Bears news conference that could not take place at another Chicago location. We have too many questions to make any decision about the value of these plans. We encourage the Bears and the administration to act with \"honor, integrity, transparency, wisdom and to be forward thinking and collaborative\" and not repeat past mistakes.\n\n* WTTW...\n\nA city ordinance prohibits private development east of DuSable Lake Shore Drive. [...]\n\nJohnson was also hit with questions about the potential for lawsuits from Friends of the Parks, who previously sued to help prevent a George Lucas lakefront museum.\n\n\"What we're preparing This is the day to build the momentum. Yeah, to pass the hat right to get 2.3 billion in taxpayer money for your new stadium.\" [00:01:04][41.5] PFT\n\nThe new stadium is expected to cost $4.6 billion, and the team is expected to ask the residents of Chicago to agree to a tax hike to pay $2.3 billion of the stadium's cost.\n\nDespite buying land in Chicago suburb, Bears plan to build a new lakefront stadium\n\nThe Chicago Bears purchased land in Arlington Heights, a suburb of the city of Chicago. The land featured 326 acres and was the former home of the Arlington International Racecourse. However, in March, ESPN reported that the team had decided to change course.\n\nThe club was unhappy with the property tax on the site and concluded that it would be best to remain within municipal limits. The company has now set its sights on lakefront land and plans to present designs on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe state-of-the-art stadium is also expected to have a dome that will be more accommodating for fans who have dealt with the frigid temperatures. {"uri": "2024-04-331923393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "00:35:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T00:35:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T00:13:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.chicagobusiness.com/sports/jerry-reinsdorf-offers-open-wallet-chicago-white-sox-stadium", "title": "Reinsdorf offers to open wallet for new Sox stadium", "body": "With the Chicago Bears ramping up their campaign for a new lakefront stadium, White Sox owner Jerry Reinsdorf is upping his ante for a second proposed new stadium in the South Loop that he wants a state agency to build and lease to the Sox.\n\nIn a written statement, a source close to Reinsdorf said that, despite earlier media reports indicating Reinsdorf wants the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority to front the entire $1.25 billion said to be needed for the new ballpark, \"We never said there would not be White Sox investment in the potential development.\"\n\n\"To the contrary,\" the statement continued, \"We have been looking at several scenarios which would, under the right conditions, involve significant private investment. But as everyone knows, this is an evolving situation, and once we have a clear, definitive path, we will have a clear, definitive commitment.\n\nThe statement added, \"We are aware of the importance of the overall package, beginning with the incredible benefits a new stadium at The 78 would bring to the city.\"\n\nThe statement did not define \"significant.\" But sources close to negotiations say Reinsdorf has mentioned a figure of $200 million or more.\n\nThe 78 property at Roosevelt and Clark is owned by Related Midwest, which would develop the stadium and promised residential and commercial space in a move it says would give a jolt of energy to an underdeveloped area skirting the south branch of the Chicago River. Reinsdorf previously has said he intends to invest in the residential/commercial portion of the project, but has not discussed injecting his own funds in the ballpark itself.\n\nUnder his proposal, ISFA would build and own the stadium. The team would pay rent, but construction costs would be financed by an existing tax on Chicago hotel stays and by growth in sales-tax receipts in the stadium area.\n\nThe Bears also are believed seeking to tap the hotel tax, but also have offered to put up $2 billion toward the estimated $4.2 billion cost of the stadium on a parking lots just south of Soldier Field and related infrastructure. Sources close to the deal say the Bears would get that money not from the pockets of the team-owning McCaskey family but mostly from fans in the form of seat-purchase licenses, from the sale of naming rights to the new facility, and from a stadium-construction fund operated by the National Football League.\n\nMajor League Baseball has no similar fund, and Reinsdorf's team plays at least 81 home games a year compared to a minimum of 10 regular and pre-season games for the Bears. But the NFL team lately has been quicker on the public relations draw, announcing today that it will disclose details of its proposal at a high-level VIP event at Soldier Field on April 24.\n\nReinsdorf's offer to open his wallet also comes after a recent statement from Mayor Brandon Johnson that the billionaire needs to \"put some skin in the game\" to advance his stadium plan. At the same time, Johnson has had a series of what are described as cordial talks with Bears owners and officials about their plans.\n\nIt's not clear whether the financing frameworks being advanced by either team will be sufficient to satisfy Gov. J.B. Pritzker, who harbors national political ambitions and has said he's leery about giving taxpayer subsidies to wealth sporting team owners.\n\nThe Bears have hoped to pass a needed authorization measure in the spring session of the General Assembly. But that increasingly appears to be a long shot with lawmakers girding for fall elections and preparing to adjourn for the summer around Memorial Day.\n\nThe Bears at one point seemed set on moving to Arlington Heights and purchased the site of the former Arlington International Racecourse. But the team appears to have soured on that in favor of a Chicago lakefront location.", "source": {"uri": "chicagobusiness.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crain's Chicago Business"}, "authors": {"uri": "8094718941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:45:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:45:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:45:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://abc7chicago.com/chicago-bears-to-announce-new-stadium-details-at-press-conference-wednesday-plans-call-for-dome-along-lakefront/14725607/", "title": "Chicago Bears set to announce details for new domed lakefront stadium", "body": "CHICAGO (WLS) -- The Chicago Bears will hold a news conference Wednesday to detail the team's plans for a new lakefront stadium.\n\nThe Bears are set to unveil plans for a state-of-the-art, domed lakefront stadium. The team is asking for the cost to be covered by a combination of public and private funding.\n\nSports marketing expert Marc Gannis said there certainly are benefits for having a domed stadium in a city like Chicago, which could attract other major events in the future.\n\n\"There are significant benefits to building a dome stadium in a city like Chicago,\" Gannis said. \"It will attract not just a Super Bowl every decade or so but on an ongoing basis it will be the attraction for major events.\"\n\nRELATED: Bears want taxpayers to help pay for their new stadium, experts say city unlikely to get revenue\n\nOther economists ABC7 spoke with said cities rarely see a return on their investment, especially with football stadiums, given how few games there are and with ticketholders being local.\n\nAccording to the Journal of Policy Analysis and Management, since 2020 taxpayers have paid about $750 million toward construction costs of eight new stadiums or arenas across the four major sports leagues.\n\n\"That is usually the selling point, we can have development we can have whatsoever. The evidence is overwhelming: these make very poor investments,\" said Allen Sanderson, University of Chicago economics professor.\n\nRELATED: Former Gov. Patt Quinn proposes referendum on use of taxpayer money to fund Chicago sports stadiums\n\nSanderson doubts there will be enough special events and ticket sales year round at a new domed stadium to generate enough revenue for the city.\n\nThe Bears are also set to announce more green space along the Museum Campus and lakefront.\n\nThe news conference is scheduled to begin at noon.", "source": {"uri": "8095725495", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:00:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:00:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:00:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2024/04/24/chicago-bears-fans-stadium-south-lakefront-tailgate-parking-concession-lsd", "title": "Chicago Bears fans excited to see new stadium in city: 'A win-win'", "body": "A proposal for a new domed stadium along the lakefront, just south of Soldier Field, has many Bears fans excited that the team will be staying in the city.\n\nThe Bears unveiled its plan for the project, which could cost up to $4.7 billion, Wednesday afternoon. Many fans said they are looking forward to a new stadium, although some have mixed feelings about the proposed location change from Arlington Heights.\n\nFor Robby Glick, owner of the Bears fan hub Reggie's, the stadium staying on the lakefront means good business. Shuttles from the bar at 2105 S. State St. take as many as 900 people to and from Soldier Field on game days.\n\n\"Them staying there is great for us, but as a fan, I would not want the Bears to move out of the city of Chicago,\" said Glick, 60. \"Hopefully they learned their lesson because I was a season ticket holder and they didn't get much right with the current stadium.\"\n\nGlick and other fans said Soldier Field is lacking in several areas, with not enough parking, bad concessions and long bathroom lines, among other complaints. He hopes they do better with the new stadium, adding that the renderings look \"phenomenal.\"\n\nWith the fixed dome roof, Glick is optimistic Chicago will get a Super Bowl soon -- and that he won't have to freeze during colder months of the season.\n\nCourtney Fong, a Bears fan from the Northern suburbs who runs a season ticket holders Facebook group, said he's hopeful the stadium will mean more opportunities to host big events and bring more revenue and jobs to the city.\n\n\"I'll still say that I think that the Bears will play in the Super Bowl before we host one,\" he said.\n\nThe Bears' plans also include developing the surrounding area with a hotel, bars and restaurants, and taxpayer funded improvements to roads and other infrastructure make the area more accessible.\n\nFor some fans, more development makes the area more of a destination. Tim Shanley, founder of the Chicago Bears Tailgate Club, lives in Austin, Texas, but flies in for every home game. Shanley, 64, said that development could be \"a gamechanger.\"\n\n\"If you've ever been to a Bears game, you know how hard it is to get there, it's like it's on an island,\" Shanley said. \"To have all that in there, the whole package like that, to revitalize the area, I think it's a smart idea.\"\n\nBut others worry it will come at the expense of parking and will increase congestion.\n\n\"Traffic has already been a mess down there, and with all of the adjacent things, it's great that we'll have more space, but it also means more people,\" Fong said.\n\nSpace is one reason some fans feel conflicted about the Bears' decision not to move forward with the Arlington Heights location.\n\nDennis Lindley, 53, from Aurora, said he has mixed feelings about the stadium plans. While he said he enjoys the lakefront games, Arlington Heights would have some benefits.\n\n\"I think there'll be more room potentially out in Arlington Heights for parking lots and tailgates, to meet up with friends before the game,\" Lindley said. \"We have friends come in from Wisconsin and Indiana, Iowa, all the time, and it's a chance to meet, but in Chicago it's difficult.\"\n\nAlthough the funding for the plan remains unclear and it could require some taxpayer dollars, some fans said the revenue it will generate and improvements to the area justify it. Glick said with the events a domed stadium can host, the cost will be worth it.\n\n\"One way or another, I guess we're all kind of paying for it because it's gonna raise the prices,\" Lindley said. So it's a little confusing as far as them talking about coming back into Chicago. They seem to have worked some things out, and the mayor seems to think it is all fine and dandy and done, but I'm just not sold on it yet because that (Arlington Heights) property has the opportunity to bring in so much money for the organization.\"\n\nOn expectations the Bears will take Caleb Williams with the No. 1 pick:\n\n\"It's an opportunity for the Bears to restart their clock with a fresh quarterback. You're bringing in a quarterback that has skills, has talents that have to be refined. When you look at it, you're almost bringing in a young guy in the same position that (Justin) Fields was in when he left. {"uri": "8095698020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:26:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/football/s-3218406", "title": "Bears unveil their lakefront stadium plans as Gov. J.B. Pritzker says 'I remain skeptical'", "body": "CHICAGO -- The Chicago Bears -- one of the National Football League's charter franchises -- on Wednesday unveiled plans for a new stadium project on the lakefront partly funded by the public that would give the team a facility in line with many of the NFL's ultra-modern, fan-friendly structures.\n\nJoined by Mayor Brandon Johnson and other local political leaders, team officials held a noontime news conference at their current home -- 100-year-old Soldier Field -- where they detailed what the multipurpose, fix-roofed, 77,000-capacity stadium and surrounding area would look like and sketched out how the plan would be funded.\n\nAbsent from the event was Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker, who earlier in the day repeated his skepticism of a plan that relies on public funding.\n\nBut Bears team President and CEO Kevin Warren called it \"a special day.\"\n\nJohnson said the project would \"result in no new taxes on the residents of Chicago.\" He and Warren rattled off the community benefits and big-name events the project would bring, like Super Bowls, Final Fours and concerts.\n\nThe stadium would be owned by the Chicago Park District, the team said.\n\nKaren Murphy, the team's executive vice president of stadium development and chief operating officer, said the project would cost more than $4.6 billion. The stadium would cost $3.225 billion with up to $1.4 billion for infrastructure.\n\nThe Bears would commit more than $2 billion to what she called one of the biggest private investments into a public facility in Illinois history. All of the team's investment would pay for 72% of the stadium itself, with a Chicago hotel tax helping fund the rest plus all the infrastructure costs.\n\nThe project would require an increase in bonding by the Illinois State Facilities Bonding Authority.\n\nThe proposal includes 14 acres of athletic fields and recreational park space, with restrooms for the public. one of the league's most storied franchises unveiled a monster plan highlighted by a $5billion proposal for a new domed lakefront stadium.\n\nIt wasn't long ago that the Bears were threatening to take their team to the Chicago suburbs.\n\nWith Williams set to share a stage with NFL commissioner Roger Goodell on Thursday night in Detroit, the Bears attempted to capitalize on the Williams buzz by announcing a massive project that would transform the city's iconic lakefront area and push Chicago to the top in the race to have the best and newest stadium in the country.\n\n\"This is not an easy project, but Chicago doesn't like it easy,\" Bears president Kevin Warren said.\n\nChicago's citizens will play a pivotal role in the final decision whether to build or not to build, since more than $2 billion in public financing will be required.\n\nFans were divided on the proposal, which was accompanied by a sleek video that saw the potential new stadium and surrounding area appearing like a scene in a new Star Wars movie.\n\n\"Where are we gonna park?\" one fan tweeted.\n\n\"My favorite part is keeping the old columns from Soldier Field,\" a second fan posted. \"So much great history The stadium will have a translucent roof and massive windows showcasing the Chicago skyline. The surrounding development includes more than a dozen acres of green space including athletic fields and public parks and phased-in infrastructure improvements to the lakefront campus.\n\nThe proposal calls for a $2 billion investment from the Bears, with a $300 million loan from the National Football League and a $900 million debt sale from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority.\n\nJohnson lauded the Bears $2 billion commitment to the project as one of the largest private investments in the city's history. He said there will not be any new or raised taxes on Chicago residents. Kevin Warren, president of the Bears, said the team is seeking to be fiscally responsible in its plans, noting it opted for a fixed roof, instead of a retractable one given the cost.\n\n\"For any new development project at the lakefront, we required real private investment, real public use and real economic participation for the entire city,\" Johnson said. \"Today's announcement delivers on all They also released renderings, showing their physical outlay for the museum/lakefront campus.\n\nSoldier Field, which has been constructed and standing for nearly 100 years, is absent from the renderings. The historic columns, which are part of the architecture that \"pays homage to the men and women who valiantly served the country,\" according to Landmarks Illinois, remain in the renderings.\n\n\"Sports fields and gardens will replace the current stadium, with Soldier Field's historic colonnades preserved as a tribute to Chicago's military veterans,\" the team said in a release. \"An enclosed stadium is essential for Chicago to attract year-round events like the Super Bowl and major concerts -- unlocking billions in tourism revenue.\"\n\n\"As you noticed here, the plan is to keep the historical columns from Soldier Field to make that part of this development to make it one museum campus,\" Bears CEO/President Kevin Warren said during a visual presentation of the renderings. \"What happens here is the additional open and green space. This will have 14 acres of athletic fields, a recreational park to allow, as I mentioned earlier, for youth to be able to come together and do things in a productive manner.\"\n\nAs for the transition to the new stadium, Warren said the Bears will play at Soldier Field until the construction of the new stadium is complete for them to play in.\n\n\"One of the things that makes the project unique is that we would be able to continue to play at Soldier Field during the construction and then to be able to move into the new stadium once the construction is finalized,\" Warren said. \"So yes, we would be able to continue to play here and not have to move to a different location.\"\n\nSoldier Field earned historical landmark status in 1987 but lost its status in 2006 as a result of renovations made to the stadium in 2003. {"uri": "2024-04-334428433", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:33:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:33:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/chicago-bears-unveil-4-7-200616948.html", "title": "Chicago Bears Unveil $4.7 Billion Stadium Plan on Lakefront", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Chicago Bears officials alongside Mayor Brandon Johnson unveiled plans for a $4.7 billion project to build a publicly owned, enclosed stadium and enhanced lakefront area.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nThe proposal involves erecting a new stadium that would cost about $3.2 billion. The stadium will have a translucent roof and massive windows showcasing the Chicago skyline. The surrounding development includes more than a dozen acres of green space including athletic fields and public parks and phased-in infrastructure improvements to the lakefront campus.\n\nThe stadium proposal calls for a $2 billion investment from the Bears, with a $300 million loan from the National Football League and a $900 million debt sale from the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, which collects a 2% tax on hotel stays.\n\n\"For any new development project at the lakefront, we required real private investment, real public use and real economic participation for the entire city,\" Johnson said. \"Today's announcement delivers on all three.\"\n\nThe project's related infrastructure would be funded in stages, with $325 million initially required for transportation, roadways and utility improvements, according to the presentation from team officials. Phase two would include $510 million for parking, the expansion of the bus depot and new parks and athletic fields. An optional third stage would provide $665 million for further transit improvements, retail space and public attractions. Officials said they were exploring a range of funding options from state, local and federal officials.\n\n\"Now is the time to act,\" said Karen Murphy, executive vice president for stadium development for the Bears. The cost of the project rises by more than $150 million every year it gets delayed partly because inflation, she estimated.\n\nJohnson lauded the Bears' $2 billion commitment to the project as one of the largest private investments in the city's history. He said there will not be any new or raised taxes on Chicago residents. Kevin Warren, president of the Bears, said the team is seeking to be fiscally responsible in its plans, noting it opted for a fixed roof, instead of a retractable one given the cost.\n\nThe stadium would be designed by Manica Architecture, the firm behind Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas and the new Nissan Stadium in Tennessee. Supporting 43,000 construction jobs, the project will be the largest building project in the region's history, according to the Bear's presentation. The team estimates the development will bring $8.4 billion in regional economic impact -- though economists say such projections are often inflated.\n\nPublic Dollars for Pro Sports\n\nThe plan comes as public financing for professional sports stadiums faces skepticism from taxpayers in other cities. Earlier this month, Kansas City voters rejected a proposal to fund a downtown ballpark for their Major League Baseball franchise and pay for improvements to Arrowhead Stadium, home to their Super-Bowl-winning team, the Kansas City Chiefs.\n\nWhile Chicago is known as a sports town, the nation's third-largest city also has a history of shaky finances. The city's pensions are short more than $35 billion after years of chronic underfunding, and more than 80% of property-tax dollars go toward retirement payouts.\n\nIllinois has the worst credit rating among US states, with massive pension debts and a history of budget deficits, though its finances have steadied in recent years. Money for the stadium project will run up against other priorities.\n\nIllinois Governor J.B. Pritzker has previously said public funding for stadiums isn't a priority for his administration. Speaking at an unrelated event on Wednesday, Pritzker reiterated his reluctance to provide public dollars to finance a stadium even though he is a Bears fan.\n\n\"I remain skeptical about this proposal and I wonder whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers,\" he said. \"The owners of these private businesses need to put a lot more forward in order to have their dreams fulfilled and not just rely upon the taxpayers of Illinois to make that happen for them.\"\n\nA spokesperson for Illinois House Speaker Chris Welch said while the speaker is happy to continue engaging in conversations with Chicago's professional sports teams, \"in the current legislative environment, with many important budget pressures, there hasn't been a strong appetite for these projects.\"\n\n--With assistance from Randall Williams.\n\n(Updates with context throughout including comments from Illinois governor.)\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg Businessweek", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "2024-04-334433567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:41:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:41:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.chicagobusiness.com/politics/bears-stadium-plan-puts-pressure-brandon-johnson", "title": "Ringing endorsement of Bears proposal raises the political stakes for Johnson", "body": "Bears put all cards on the table for $3.2 billion lakefront stadium\n\nThe Bears would provide $2.3 billion towards the $3.2 billion stadium costs under the plan. Public subsidies would make up the difference, and taxpayers would also be on the hook for $1.5 billion in infrastructure work that would be build over three phases.\n\nJohnson's endorsement puts him far beyond the hesitance to subsidize professional stadiums expressed by Gov. J.B. Pritzker and other state leaders who will be responsible for approving the plan.\n\nIt also puts political pressure on Johnson to deliver votes in Springfield to help the Bears and could become a very public defeat if the stadium deal falls apart.\n\nWarren said today \"the time is now\" and confirmed the team is pushing for approval this spring with just five weeks left in the legislative session.\n\n\"Time is money and we do need to figure this out,\" Warren said.\n\nJohnson said the Bears \"put real skin in the game\" and championed the jobs and public amenities that would come along with the new stadium.\n\n\"This is a real opportunity to create real revenue by doing what works, which is putting people to work,\" he said. \"This is very much aligned towards and aligned with my vision for a better, stronger, safer Chicago because it invests in people, it invests in households.\"\n\nAhead of the stadium announcement, Pritzker reiterated his skepticism of providing subsidies for professional stadiums, saying \"I'm not sure this is among the highest priorities for the state.\"\n\nThe statement was echoed by State Senate President Don Harmon and House Speaker Chris Welch, with both noting they were encouraged by the Bears initial private investment offer.\n\nJohnson declined to answer a question about what he'll tell Pritzker to support the plan, but said he appreciates \"the feedback that is coming from our state partners.\"\n\nHe also sought to downplay the taxpayer dollars at stake in the project, saying no new taxes or increases to existing taxes were included in the Bears' plans.\n\nWhen the Bears and Johnson arrive in Springfield, they won't be alone. The Bears rolled out their proposal before elected officials, business and labor leaders.\n\nThey'll argue the tax revenue and jobs created by the project are worth the public investment. The Bears are also relying on civic boosterism, arguing the domed stadium would be able to host the Super Bowl, college football games and the college basketball's Final Four, both women's and men's. The team also teased musical artists had expressed interest in signing up for weeks-long residencies.\n\nSupport could also come from the City Council. Ald. Walter Burnett, 27th, who doubles as Johnson's vice mayor, said people shouldn't underestimate the large Chicago delegation in the General Assembly, arguing \"most people in Springfield don't want to be on the side of the Bears potentially not being in the city of Chicago.\"\n\nMuch of the approvals needed to greenlight the project rest with state leaders, but the city's tax revenue would not be left unbothered if the Bears' plans become reality.\n\nAs it is now, the city would remain the ultimate guarantor of the annual debt service payments made by the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority as part of the plan.\n\nJill Jaworski, the city's chief financial officer, told reporters after the event she'd be \"very pleased\" if the state took on that burden, but acknowledged it's unlikely. But Jaworski argued the Bears proposal still represents a better deal for the city.\n\nCurrently, the ISFA makes annual debt payments to pay down bonds issued to build Guaranteed Rate Field and renovate Soldier Field through revenue from a 2% tax on hotel stays in Chicago. When that revenue falls short, the difference is made up through state tax revenue that otherwise would have been sent to Chicago.\n\nJaworski said current ISFA debt payments are modeled on an anticipated 5.5% annual growth in revenue from the hotel tax, but the Bears' model is more modest at 4%. The team's plan also includes an $150 to $160 million liquidity reserve fund that could be set aside and tapped during down years.\n\n\"By assuming a lower rate, we're not building that debt service up so high, and then by adding that liquidity reserve for really down years to provide funding, we feel we're much less at risk\" she said.\n\nJaworski said the Bears' debt plan is not backloaded like the structure created by former Mayor Richard M. Daley to renovate Soldier Field that has the city looking at massive payments in the coming years.\n\nThe White Sox plan\n\nRefinancing the ISFA's current debt, providing $900 million to the Bears and establishing the reserve fund would not provide a cent to the Chicago White Sox, who are pursuing their own new ballpark in the South Loop. The Sox plan includes tapping into the ISFA to the tune of over $1 billion.\n\nMarc Ganis, a Chicago-based sports marketing expert who founded Sportscorp, said, \"I would be very surprised if the White Sox are not on the phone with their lobbyists and state legislators today saying 'wait a minute, that tax source was originally approved for the White Sox and now you're saying once our lease is done, we're not getting any of it.\"\n\nJohnson has met with White Sox owner Jerry Reinsdorf but has not embraced the team's stadium plans because, until this week, Reinsdorf had not signaled he would provide any of his own equity into the project.\n\nJaworski recently rejected an idea from the Sox to use a portion of the revenue the city receives from ticket sales at the new stadiums to help pay for them. Ganis said additional tax revenue would have to be added to the pot to raise enough cash for both team's stadiums.\n\nHe also cast doubt on the state's willingness to approve any money for stadium deals, saying Harmon gave the teams the \"blueprint for getting this approved\" and the teams are largely ignoring the advice.\n\n\"Never say never when it comes to Springfield,\" he said. \"That being said, I think Sen. Harmon's plan is the only one that might get done this year. Which is, the two teams come together with one unified plan.\"\n\nGanis also said having Johnson's support doesn't necessarily mean the Bears can push something through in Springfield, citing his relative inexperience as mayor and questioning whether his progressive political base would make it a priority.", "source": {"uri": "chicagobusiness.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crain's Chicago Business"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsidy", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Subsidy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren,_Ohio", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Warren, Ohio"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Warren, Ohio"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Illinois", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Springfield, Illinois"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Springfield, Illinois"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nWarren's statement signaled a shift in focus away from building a new home in the suburbs.\n\nSoldier Field has been the Bears' home since 1971. The team's lease there runs through 2033.\n\nThe Bears spent $197.2 million more than a year ago to purchase the site of the shuttered Arlington International Racecourse from Churchill Downs Inc. in suburban Arlington Heights. The team envisioned building a stadium on the 326-acre (131 hectare) tract of land some 30 miles (48 kilometers) northwest of Soldier Field, with restaurants, retail and more on the property -- all for about $5 billion, with some taxpayer help.\n\nThe Bears said they would pay for the stadium in Arlington Heights, with taxpayer dollars covering infrastructure costs such as roads and sewers. Those plans stalled, with the team citing a property assessment it said was too high.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson has made it clear he wants to keep the team in the city.\n\n\"I have said all along that meaningful private investment and a strong emphasis on public benefit are my requirements for public-private partnerships in our city,\" Johnson said last month.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095352626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:19:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:19:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:19:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/wrigley-field-soldier-field-where-165400125.html", "title": "From Wrigley Field to Soldier Field: Where the Chicago Bears have played home games since 1921", "body": "The Chicago Bears' history started in Decatur in 1920 when the Staley Starch Company decided to sponsor a football team.\n\nIn 1921, the company gave George Halas the team, $5,000 and permission to move the team to Chicago if he would agree to keep the Staleys name for a year. The Staleys won the 1921 league championship. A year later, the team was renamed the Bears.\n\nThe Bears primarily have played home games at Wrigley Field and then Soldier Field, but a sprinkling of other venues also have hosted the team. Here's a look back at them -- and how the Bears have fared on those turfs.\n\nRecord: 221-89-22 (Two of the regular season victories came with the Bears as the \"road\" team against the Chicago Tigers)\n\nThe Bears played at Wrigley Field, previously known as Cubs Park, for their first five decades in Chicago. The team won nearly 70% of its home games during that span.\n\nWrigley Field is where University of Illinois star Harold \"Red\" Grange played his first game for the Bears on Nov. 26, 1925, in front of 36,000 fans. (The Bears and Cardinals fought to a scoreless tie, with Grange gaining 36 yards on the ground.) It's also where the Bears became the first team in the championship era (since 1933) to win back-to-back titles by routing the Giants 37-9 on Dec. 21, 1941. And where \"Kansas Comet\" Gale Sayers scored six touchdowns -- tying an NFL record -- as a rookie in a 61-20 win against the San Francisco 49ers on Dec. 12, 1965.\n\nIn 1921, the Bears, then known as the Staleys, won the American Professional Football Association title. And it wouldn't be their last. While at Wrigley, the Bears would win NFL titles in 1932, 1933, 1940, 1941, 1943, 1946 and 1963.\n\nThe team played its last game at Wrigley Field on Dec. 13, 1970. The NFL had been pressuring the Bears to move because seating capacity was less than 50,000 -- one of the parameters the league created after the AFL-NFL merger -- and because the stadium lacked lights. Jack Concannon had his best game in the finale as a Bear, throwing four touchdown passes and scoring a fifth, in a 35-17 win over the Green Bay Packers.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nThe Bears, known as the Staleys then, returned to their birthplace of Decatur to play the Rock Island Independents on Oct. 10, 1921.\n\n\"Six thousand former service men and visitors attending the American Legion convention,\" observed the game, the Tribune reported. The Bears won 14-10.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nAs the home team, the Bears went undefeated at the Sheffield Avenue facility. They beat the Hammond Pros 28-7 on Oct. 11, 1925.\n\nMilton Romney, a University of Chicago graduate and first cousin once removed of Sen. Mitt Romney, started as a fullback opposite Notre Dame grad Johnny Mohardt.\n\nRecord: 0-0-1\n\n\"Ten thousand opening-day fans watched the elevens struggle up and down the dusty gridiron to a scoreless tie,\" the Tribune reported.\n\nThe Bears met the Brooklyn Dodgers at the West Side stadium on Sept. 21, 1930. Both teams managed to rack up 15 first downs, but no points. Bears fullback Bronko Nagurski recovered a fumble late in the game, but the Bears' final effort to score was halted at Brooklyn's goal line.\n\nGrange scored the Bears' first touchdown of the season \"when he crashed off Cleveland's left tackle on a delayed plunge,\" the Tribune reported.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nSnow and freezing temperatures turned Wrigley into the North (Side) Pole and forced the Bears vs. Portsmouth (Ohio) Spartans game for the NFL title indoors at Chicago Stadium to play on a 60-yard field before more than 11,000 fans. It was the first NFL game to be played indoors, according to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nOn Dec. 18, 1932, the Bears won 9-0 for their second title.\n\nThe 1932 NFL championship. Indoors at Chicago Stadium. How one of the strangest -- and most influential -- games in Bears history changed the league.\n\nBears owner Virginia Halas McCaskey was a seventh grader at the time and had a lasting memory of the game.\n\n\"Just the odor,\" she said with a laugh during a Tribune interview in March 2019. \"It was almost overwhelming because the circus had just left town.\"\n\nDespite winning 20-16, reviews of the Bears' performance were brutal.\n\n\"The Bears committed almost every possible type of football sin. They were penalized for almost every foul in the book,\" Tribune sports editor Cooper Rollow wrote.\n\nEvanston didn't think much of the Bears either. Residents petitioned city officials to block the Bears from moving there. The Bears signed a five-year deal with Northwestern in early 1971, but the Big Ten Conference denied permission for the team to lease Dyche Stadium two weeks later.\n\nRecord: 234-176-2\n\nThe Bears relocated to Soldier Field -- where they had played on occasion previously, including as the \"away team\" against the Cardinals in 1926 -- for the start of the 1971 season. The team chose it over Comiskey Park. With the exception of one season in 2002 during stadium renovations, the downtown Chicago stadium on the lakefront has been their home ever since.\n\nThe new era began with a win over the Pittsburgh Steelers, 17-15 on Sept. 19, 1971, in the rain. Capacity was cut to 57,000 fans.\n\nChicago's Soldier Field: A timeline of events since 1924, including hosting the world's athletes, congregations, politicians and performers\n\nSoldier Field is where Walter Payton pummeled the Minnesota Vikings for 275 yards on Nov. 20, 1977, breaking O.J. Simpson's single-game NFL record of 273 yards on a 4-yard, fourth-down, fourth-quarter run that was stopped short of the first down. On Dec. 16, 1979 to news that George \"Mugs\" Halas, Jr., team president and son of the owner/founder, had died unexpectedly overnight, the Bears rallied to rout the St. Louis Cardinals 42-6 and earn a wild-card berth. Other memorable moments include a 61-7 win over the Green Bay Packers on Dec. 7, 1980 (though the Bears were eliminated from playoff contention after the Minnesota Vikings beat the Tampa Bay Buccaneers). And a 20-12 win over the Eagles in the 1988 NFC playoffs known as \"The Fog Bowl.\"\n\nA championship didn't come easily, or quickly, to Soldier Field's residents. It took 14 seasons for the Bears to bring a title home, winning Super Bowl XX in 1986 with a 46-10 rout of the New England Patriots. It was the team's ninth and most recent title. The Bears did earn a dramatic trip to Super Bowl XLI by defeating the New Orleans Saints 39-14 in the NFC championship game on Jan. 21, 2007, at Soldier Field -- and the George Halas Trophy was presented to Halas' daughter and team owner Virginia McCaskey.\n\nRecord: 3-5\n\nWhile Mayor Richard M. Daley and the Chicago Park District were busy remodeling Soldier Field, the Bears moved down to Champaign to play \"home\" games at the University of Illinois' Memorial Stadium.\n\nNote: The Bears often played at Comiskey Park and Normal Park, but the Cardinals were the home team.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-04-335285617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:51:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.chicagobusiness.com/sports/arlington-heights-mayor-chicago-bears-were-happy-be-plan-b", "title": "Arlington Heights mayor on the Bears: 'We're happy to be Plan B'", "body": "That was the bottom line of an interview with the village's mayor, Tom Hayes, on 670-AM's \"Mully and Haugh Show\" this morning. The hosts asked Hayes to react to the presentation Bears CEO Kevin Warren made yesterday -- a glitzy pitch to build a domed stadium on the lakefront just south of the team's current home, Soldier Field.\n\n\"It's pretty clear based on Kevin Warren's stated desire to remain on the lakefront that that's their first option,\" Hayes said. \"We're very happy to be Plan B or Plan 1A, whatever you want to call it at this point. We're waiting in the wings if they do get a 'no' on the lakefront,\" he added, alluding to the potential obstacles to the Bears current plan. Those obstacles include a possible legal challenge from advocacy group Friends of the Parks as well as a potential rejection of the Bears' public subsidy asks in Springfield.\n\nIn a similar vein, school districts that would serve the residential development earlier envisioned for the Bears' property in Arlington Heights have challenged tax breaks for the team, but Hayes said he believes those are short-term issues that can be \"easily resolved if the Bears do get a 'no' on the lakefront and turn back in our direction.\"\n\nThe Bears made a deal to purchase the Arlington Heights property for $197.2 million while Ted Phillips was still CEO, and closed on the purchase in 2023 after laying out an ambitious plan for residential, retail and entertainment developments in addition to the stadium. That plan took advantage of the site's built-in Metra access as well as proximity to highways. The 326-acre site has been razed and is now development-ready.\n\nSince then, Warren has replaced Phillips and shifted the team's priority to the lakefront. One hitch for the Bears, even under Warren's leadership, is that the team won't own a stadium on Chicago Park District land, Hayes pointed out.\n\n\"What the Bears told us from Day One was that they were looking to own their own stadium and to build ... a dining and entertainment district and provide a game day experience that would provide substantially more revenue than what they are realizing at Soldier Field down on the lakefront.\"", "source": {"uri": "chicagobusiness.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crain's Chicago Business"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rutherford B. {"uri": "8097085465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:15:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:15:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:15:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/nfl/column-suuuure-give-the-chicago-bears-whatever-they-want-for-a-new-stadium-after-that/article_88765123-615d-5635-a16b-e8d45706313d.html", "title": "Column: Suuuure, give the Chicago Bears whatever they want for a new stadium after that pitch", "body": "Paul Sullivan, Chicago Tribune\n\nYou have to give the Chicago Bears and Mayor Brandon Johnson credit for their boldness.\n\nName-dropping the likes of Daniel Burnham, former President Barack Obama, Taylor Swift and Beyonce on Wednesday during their presentation of a proposed $4.6 billion stadium project was pure genius.\n\nHighlighting the historic Soldier Field colonnades after hiding them behind the crash-landing spaceship from the previous stadium renovation while talking about the need to \"respect and embrace our traditions\" was gaslighting at its finest.\n\nInforming us that \"no new taxes\" would be necessary to pay for the project was what everyone wanted to hear, even though public funding of at least $1 billion probably would be necessary to get a deal done.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases NCHS placed on 'hold' Wednesday morning; students and staff safe Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway District 87 teachers get first look at newly purchased Oakland Avenue Building Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington Coroner: Pekin woman dead after forklift accident in Goodfield Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection Illinois State basketball adds former Northern Iowa guard\n\nFinally, announcing the plan the day before the Bears are expected to select quarterback Caleb Williams with the first pick in the NFL draft was a marketing coup, a much better idea than announcing it the day after another loss to the Green Bay Packers.\n\nEverything seemed to be fine, and if the Bears get their wish, a new stadium would be ready in time for the 2028 season, when Williams should be gunning for his second Super Bowl.\n\nAfter seeing the renderings and listening to Bears President and CEO Kevin Warren talk about the Super Bowls, Final Fours, Illinois high school football championships and concerts that would take place in the new stadium, how could anyone dare say no to this idea?\n\n\"If that doesn't make your teeth chatter, I don't know what will,\" Warren said after the release of the renderings.\n\nObviously Warren never has sat in the stands at a Bears game in subzero weather or he would know the only thing in Chicago that would make one's teeth chatter is watching a bad team while freezing your butt off. I have, and I can't say it's comparable to seeing the renderings.\n\nChicago Bears release images of a proposed new lakefront stadium\n\nBut they did look kind of cool, just as the renderings for the proposed White Sox Park in the South Loop looked terrific. I'm guessing the renderings of the new Comiskey Park and the Soldier Field renovation also looked cool when they were revealed, because anything new and futuristic looking is bound to appear better than the status quo.\n\nMaybe there will even be more bathrooms, and video boards that you won't have to crane your neck to see?\n\nLet's do it.\n\nNaturally, Gov. J.B. Pritzker immediately threw cold water on the Bears' and Johnson's big day, saying he was \"skeptical\" and wondering \"whether it's a good deal for the taxpayers.\" That's the easiest way to put the kibosh on the project without actually looking into whether it would be a good thing for the city and the McCaskeys, the public and private part of the public-private venture.\n\nFunding should not be an issue. Warren told the Tribune editorial board that the 30-year bonds for U.S. Bank Stadium, which he got built in Minnesota, were paid off 23 years ahead of schedule because of revenues from e-pull tabs, a gambling game that's like a lottery ticket.\n\nEditorial: The Bears may stir Chicago's blood with splashy pitch for a lakefront stadium. We're not convinced.\n\nIf extending the 2% hotel tax for another 40 years is a problem for Pritzker, perhaps the Bears can instead propose an added 2% tax on adult-use cannabis sales in Illinois. That should pay off the bonds for the new stadium in no time, as anyone who ever got a contact high from strolling through the tailgate parties on the Waldron Deck, the proposed site of the stadium, can attest.\n\nThe nonprofit Friends of the Park likely will try to butt in, as they did when they drove away the last billionaire who wanted to build something -- a \"Star Wars\" themed museum -- on our cherished lakefront.\n\nBut this is not an ego-driven project promoting an overrated sci-fi movie that appeals only to nerds. This is our beloved Bears, even though they're owned by the not-so-beloved McCaskeys. Who elected these \"Friends\" anyways? Can't they find something to do inside for once in their lives?\n\nTime is of the essence, the Bears warned us, with the cost expected to go up by $150 million or so every wasted year without a shovel in the ground.\n\nIf you can't bear the idea of helping out the billionaire McCaskeys, do it for all the kids who would benefit from what was touted as 20% more open space from the removal of the crashed spaceship and turning the current field into a park -- albeit with better sod, I'm guessing.\n\nOr think about Johnson's inauguration ceremony at the new stadium, as he bizarrely fantasized about Wednesday during his rambling pep-rally speech that ended with the words \"God bless the greatest freaking city in the world.\"\n\nThat's our mayor, an orator for the ages.\n\nOr think about poor Beyonce not having to worry about performing in the rain, as almost happened last summer, we were informed at the presentation. Not only would the new translucent roof protect fans from dreaded \"Bear weather,\" it would keep pop stars such as Beyonce and Swift warm and dry.\n\nThere are so many reasons to get this done it boggles the mind, and the sooner the better before the White Sox ask for their handout.\n\nThe No. 1 reason, of course, is the possibility of a getting Super Bowl down the road.\n\n\"How many people would love to come to a Super Bowl in Chicago?\" Johnson asked, before answering his own question:\n\n\"Everyone.\"\n\nA week in Chicago in February over Phoenix or Miami? It's a no-brainer.\n\nThere were plenty of unanswered questions about financing, parking, tailgating, PSLs and whether anyone will be able to find the Uber lot after a game. The 1.4-mile walk from the Roosevelt Road \"L\" station would still be a half-hour to the Waldron Deck site, but maybe they'll have room in the infrastructure budget for a people mover.\n\nAnyway, Bears, you had me at \"Fear the roar.\"\n\nSo bye-bye, spaceship, and so long, Bear weather.\n\nAs Burnham said: Make no little plans when you can have a translucent roof instead.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Um ... come again?\n\nThe Bears want exactly $3.2 billion to build the stadium, as well as an extra $1.5 billion for infrastructure. The project will add green, open space, improve access to the Museum Campus and also feature a publicly owned hotel -- nothing at all that affects the public directly. {"uri": "8096811377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:18:56", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:18:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:18:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "http://blockclubchicago.org/2024/04/25/block-club-readers-weigh-in-on-the-bears-4-6-billion-stadium-proposal/", "title": "Block Club Readers Weigh In On The Bears $4.6 Billion Stadium Proposal", "body": "DOWNTOWN -- The Chicago Bears unveiled designs for a $4.6 billion lakefront stadium proposal, which includes a $3.2 billion facility plus another $1.4 billion in infrastructure improvements.\n\nAnd Chicagoans had thoughts.\n\nUnder the plan, Soldier Field would be demolished and replaced with sports fields and gardens, team leaders said. The stadium's historic colonnades would be preserved.\n\nWhile Mayor Brandon Johnson has supported it, Gov. JB Pritzker, park advocates and other local officials slammed the idea of building a facility on public parkland and using taxpayer dollars for the project.\n\nWe asked you what you thought. Here's what you said. Some responses have been edited for clarity.\n\n\"Love the new stadium proposal! While I prefer an open air stadium, they need this for hosting big events and the city can't lose the bears and opportunity to host events Downtown.\" -Dan, West Town\n\n\"I do love the idea of a Downtown domed stadium, mostly because of the opportunity to host the Super Bowl or Final Four. Wish it was retractable because indoor football really sucks, especially when most of the fall weather is amazing. I question if they really will be able to make getting in and out better. Parking is not going to be sufficient nor the space to tailgate. Why not build this sucker where the Sox want to move? The synergy of what they have in Baltimore is amazing with the Ravens and the O's parks right near each other. In general, I think the lakefront location is really dumb. There's so many other spaces in proximity to Downtown that are not as difficult to get in and out of.\" -Paul Moretta\n\n\"My thoughts. NO, JUST NO. The Chicago Bears can afford to build somewhere else, not on the lakefront and without using any public/government money. Arlington Heights would be fine, they already have the land and a Metra station. Also, they should be required to return Soldier Field to its landmark status.\" -Michael, Logan Square\n\n\"The upgrade to Museum Campus, from the green space to the new dome, looks wonderful. But I think the administration is being disingenuous about funding.\n\n\"It's the same with changes to school funding. We can't spend more money without either cutting elsewhere or raising funds (or both).\n\n\"The playbook seems to be: 1. Announce something new that will undoubtedly cost extra funds. 2. Hand wave concerns about where the money will come from.\n\n\"TBD how successful this approach will be.\" -Walter, University Village\n\n\"It is well documented that the financial returns on large stadiums is poor.\n\n\"When you have a city like Chicago, the returns will likely cost several generations of taxpayers. City officials stated how many jobs and all the benefits of the 2002 Soldier Field renovation. In the name of the taxpayers, they borrowed $398 million. Twenty-two years later, we now owe $640 million, and by the time it is supposed to be paid off in about 10 years it will have cost taxpayers $1.1 billion. (Editor note: The outstanding tab was $640 million as of 2022. It is around $584 million now, according to NBC Chicago).\n\n\"Mayor Brandon has already proven himself to be fiscally irresponsible with the deals and borrowing he's done already.\n\n\"This should be put up to a referendum on this November's ballot. The taxpayers should decide if we want to saddle ourselves with billlions more in debt.\" -Leon Greenberg, Lakeview East\n\n\"If they are going to spend all that money why can't it be a retractable roof?\" -Travis Schulz, Old Town\n\n\"As a Chicago taxpayer, I'm totally opposed to any public funding of a new Bears stadium. This is their stadium that they will profit from. They should pay for it, like the Cubs paid for their Wrigley renovations. Period.\n\n\"I'm also opposed to demolishing Soldier Field. I consider it an iconic Chicago landmark.\" -Dennis Davis, Jefferson Park\n\n\"Possibly the most vulgar plan to reach into taxpayers' pockets I can imagine. And that's before we get to the premise of grabbing public parkland that even they acknowledge to be the most attractive in the world.\" -Wayne Hoppe, Gold Coast\n\n\"Seems to have missed the mark aesthetically and only 65,000 seats? The green space is too busy ... jumbled ... the museum campus is classical and symmetrical and widely spaced.\n\n\"Why not make the Soldier Field space also suitable for concerts in 20,000 range so Huntington Bank Pavilion on Northerly Island could be returned to green space? Also major festivals could move here from neighborhood parks. Also can't hotel and sports museum go west of Lake Shore Drive on land at 16th Street? There is already an underpass, with another underpass at 13th Street. Current plan needs major re-work.\" -George Spalek, Lakeview\n\n\"Before the McCaskeys/Bears get one penny from the city, the existing bonds should be paid off, with significant assistance from the Bears. Unlikely, I realize. I don't like the idea of millionaires/billionaires getting money from the taxpayers in sweetheart deals. Studies have shown the benefits to the hosting city usually are not as substantial as promised.\n\nLet the Bears put more skin in the game. The city gets a significant percentage of all net profits (with agreed upon accounting principals) until the bonds are paid off. The city profits if the Bears profit. We share the risk in getting those bonds paid off; we should be sharing the profits until the debt/bonds are paid off.\" -Irene R., the Loop", "source": {"uri": "blockclubchicago.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Block Club Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soldier_Field", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Soldier Field"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Los_Angeles", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Downtown Los Angeles"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Downtown Los Angeles"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Bears", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Chicago Bears"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dome", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Dome"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "New Orleans Saints"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_men's_basketball_tournament", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._Pritzker", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "8095317402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/04/24/chicago-bears-home-game-stadiums/", "title": "From Wrigley Field to Soldier Field: Where the Chicago Bears have played home games since 1921", "body": "The Chicago Bears' history started in Decatur in 1920 when the Staley Starch Company decided to sponsor a football team.\n\nIn 1921, the company gave George Halas the team, $5,000 and permission to move the team to Chicago if he would agree to keep the Staleys name for a year. The Staleys won the 1921 league championship. A year later, the team was renamed the Bears.\n\nThe Bears primarily have played home games at Wrigley Field and then Soldier Field, but a sprinkling of other venues also have hosted the team. Here's a look back at them -- and how the Bears have fared on those turfs.\n\nRecord: 221-89-22 (Two of the regular season victories came with the Bears as the \"road\" team against the Chicago Tigers)\n\nThe Bears played at Wrigley Field, previously known as Cubs Park, for their first five decades in Chicago. The team won nearly 70% of its home games during that span.\n\nWrigley Field is where University of Illinois star Harold \"Red\" Grange played his first game for the Bears on Nov. 26, 1925, in front of 36,000 fans. (The Bears and Cardinals fought to a scoreless tie, with Grange gaining 36 yards on the ground.) It's also where the Bears became the first team in the championship era (since 1933) to win back-to-back titles by routing the Giants 37-9 on Dec. 21, 1941. And where \"Kansas Comet\" Gale Sayers scored six touchdowns -- tying an NFL record -- as a rookie in a 61-20 win against the San Francisco 49ers on Dec. 12, 1965.\n\nIn 1921, the Bears, then known as the Staleys, won the American Professional Football Association title. And it wouldn't be their last. While at Wrigley, the Bears would win NFL titles in 1932, 1933, 1940, 1941, 1943, 1946 and 1963.\n\nThe team played its last game at Wrigley Field on Dec. 13, 1970. The NFL had been pressuring the Bears to move because seating capacity was less than 50,000 -- one of the parameters the league created after the AFL-NFL merger -- and because the stadium lacked lights. Jack Concannon had his best game in the finale as a Bear, throwing four touchdown passes and scoring a fifth, in a 35-17 win over the Green Bay Packers.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nThe Bears, known as the Staleys then, returned to their birthplace of Decatur to play the Rock Island Independents on Oct. 10, 1921.\n\n\"Six thousand former service men and visitors attending the American Legion convention,\" observed the game, the Tribune reported. The Bears won 14-10.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nAs the home team, the Bears went undefeated at the Sheffield Avenue facility. They beat the Hammond Pros 28-7 on Oct. 11, 1925.\n\nMilton Romney, a University of Chicago graduate and first cousin once removed of Sen. Mitt Romney, started as a fullback opposite Notre Dame grad Johnny Mohardt.\n\nRecord: 0-0-1\n\n\"Ten thousand opening-day fans watched the elevens struggle up and down the dusty gridiron to a scoreless tie,\" the Tribune reported.\n\nThe Bears met the Brooklyn Dodgers at the West Side stadium on Sept. 21, 1930. Both teams managed to rack up 15 first downs, but no points. Bears fullback Bronko Nagurski recovered a fumble late in the game, but the Bears' final effort to score was halted at Brooklyn's goal line.\n\nGrange scored the Bears' first touchdown of the season \"when he crashed off Cleveland's left tackle on a delayed plunge,\" the Tribune reported.\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nSnow and freezing temperatures turned Wrigley into the North (Side) Pole and forced the Bears vs. Portsmouth (Ohio) Spartans game for the NFL title indoors at Chicago Stadium to play on a 60-yard field before more than 11,000 fans. It was the first NFL game to be played indoors, according to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nOn Dec. 18, 1932, the Bears won 9-0 for their second title.\n\nThe 1932 NFL championship. Indoors at Chicago Stadium. How one of the strangest -- and most influential -- games in Bears history changed the league.\n\n\"Just the odor,\" she said with a laugh during a Tribune interview in March 2019. \"It was almost overwhelming because the circus had just left town.\"\n\nRecord: 1-0\n\nThe Bears traveled 16 miles north to Evanston to take on the Philadelphia Eagles at Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium (now Ryan Field) on Sept. 27, 1970.\n\nDespite winning 20-16, reviews of the Bears' performance were brutal.\n\n\"The Bears committed almost every possible type of football sin. They were penalized for almost every foul in the book,\" Tribune sports editor Cooper Rollow wrote.\n\nEvanston didn't think much of the Bears either. Residents petitioned city officials to block the Bears from moving there. The Bears signed a five-year deal with Northwestern in early 1971, but the Big Ten Conference denied permission for the team to lease Dyche Stadium two weeks later.\n\nRecord: 234-176-2\n\nThe Bears relocated to Soldier Field -- where they had played on occasion previously, including as the \"away team\" against the Cardinals in 1926 -- for the start of the 1971 season. The team chose it over Comiskey Park. With the exception of one season in 2002 during stadium renovations, the downtown Chicago stadium on the lakefront has been their home ever since.\n\nThe new era began with a win over the Pittsburgh Steelers, 17-15 on Sept. 19, 1971, in the rain. Capacity was cut to 57,000 fans.\n\nChicago's Soldier Field: A timeline of events since 1924, including hosting the world's athletes, congregations, politicians and performers\n\nSoldier Field is where Walter Payton pummeled the Minnesota Vikings for 275 yards on Nov. 20, 1977, breaking O.J. Simpson's single-game NFL record of 273 yards on a 4-yard, fourth-down, fourth-quarter run that was stopped short of the first down. On Dec. 16, 1979 to news that George \"Mugs\" Halas, Jr., team president and son of the owner/founder, had died unexpectedly overnight, the Bears rallied to rout the St. Louis Cardinals 42-6 and earn a wild-card berth. Other memorable moments include a 61-7 win over the Green Bay Packers on Dec. 7, 1980 (though the Bears were eliminated from playoff contention after the Minnesota Vikings beat the Tampa Bay Buccaneers). And a 20-12 win over the Eagles in the 1988 NFC playoffs known as \"The Fog Bowl.\"\n\nA championship didn't come easily, or quickly, to Soldier Field's residents. It took 14 seasons for the Bears to bring a title home, winning Super Bowl XX in 1986 with a 46-10 rout of the New England Patriots. It was the team's ninth and most recent title. The Bears did earn a dramatic trip to Super Bowl XLI by defeating the New Orleans Saints 39-14 in the NFC championship game on Jan. 21, 2007, at Soldier Field -- and the George Halas Trophy was presented to Halas' daughter and team owner Virginia McCaskey.\n\nRecord: 3-5\n\nWhile Mayor Richard M. Daley and the Chicago Park District were busy remodeling Soldier Field, the Bears moved down to Champaign to play \"home\" games at the University of Illinois' Memorial Stadium.\n\nNote: The Bears often played at Comiskey Park and Normal Park, but the Cardinals were the home team.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8097320554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "19:20:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T19:20:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T19:20:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/chicago-bears-face-long-shot-push-for-new-3-2-billion-stadium-1.2065296", "title": "Chicago Bears Face Long-Shot Push for New $3.2 Billion Stadium - BNN Bloomberg", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Even the Chicago Bears' long odds of winning next year's Super Bowl seem better than the team's chances of convincing Illinois lawmakers to approve $900 million of borrowing in the next few weeks to build a new $3.2 billion stadium.\n\nThe National Football League team's pitch to erect a gleaming domed stadium and revamped lakefront offers more than $2 billion in private funding from the Bears, but the ask for public dollars is already facing concern from officials who approve key financing resources and have to balance an already tight budget.\n\n\"If we were to put this issue on the board for a vote right now, it would fail and it would fail miserably,\" Illinois House Speaker Chris Welch said.\n\nIn a proposal unveiled Wednesday, the Bears would contribute the bulk of the funding toward the stadium, with an additional $300 million coming from the NFL. A key piece would be $900 million of public funds acquired through a sale of municipal bonds by the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, a government agency set up in the 1980s.\n\nThe Bears are looking for that authorization to come through before the conclusion of the current legislative session at the end of May -- giving officials roughly five weeks to decide. Proponents don't want to wait months for lawmakers to reconvene in the fall because the winter weather could delay the project, said team president Kevin Warren.\n\n\"There is no environment for something like this today,\" Welch told reporters on Wednesday. He noted that while things could change, it's \"highly unlikely\" to pivot so drastically in the next month.\n\nThe ask comes at a tough time. Illinois is facing its tightest budget in three years that includes what Governor J.B. Pritzker has called \"hard choices.\" The state -- which carries the lowest credit rating among peers even after a string of upgrades -- is trying to pass a balanced spending plan while committing hundreds of millions to care for migrants and paying down its roughly $140 billion unfunded pension liability.\n\nMaintaining the state's improved fiscal trajectory is a priority that Welch, Pritzker and other state leaders underscore repeatedly. The memories of Illinois' credit grade teetering on the brink of junk near the start of the pandemic and a two-year budget impasse before that are still fresh.\n\n\"My hope is that the timing of this is not to give the legislature the bum's rush to hurry up in the next five weeks,\" said Joe Ferguson, president of the Civic Federation, a fiscal watchdog. He said the fall session will give decision makers four to five months for an economic analysis.\n\nFerguson said Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson standing alongside team officials supporting the proposal indicates the city is not an independent party and additional outside vetting of the financial plan is necessary. The overall pitch from the Bears is for a nearly $5 billion project that includes a revamped lakefront in addition to the stadium.\n\nDebt Plan\n\nThe Bears proposal would restructure past debt sold for Soldier Field, the Bears' current stadium, and Guaranteed Rate Field, home to Major League Baseball's White Sox, by the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority and extend the maturity by 40 years, generating net new bond proceeds worth more than $1 billion, said Karen Murphy, executive vice president of stadium development for the Bears.\n\nThe debt would be backed by revenue from a 2% city hotel tax. If those funds fall short, the team plans to set up a reserve fund to cover the difference, according to Murphy.\n\nPreviously, when hotel tax revenue that the authority uses as a key source of funds has dipped -- like during fiscal 2022 and 2023 because of the pandemic -- the state is able to pull from income tax collections it sends to Chicago.\n\nFitch Ratings in December upgraded the authority two notches to BBB, taking it from junk to investment grade. The boost reflected \"the robust and sustained recovery in hotel tax revenues\" though the company warned though that a slump in stays or a \"significant unanticipated new money issuance\" may cause a downgrade.\n\n\"We'd have to see how that plays out,\" said Fitch analyst Eric Kim, noting that few details are available on the structure of the potential financing. \"We are certainly watching in terms of what is the state going to be taking on as part of this project.\"\n\nSign up for Bloomberg's Business of Sports newsletter for the context you need on the collision of power, money and
